pages.headline: Cops smash car to 'save' toy dog
pages.teaser: COPS broke car's window to save a dog baking on back seat only to find it was a TOY
pages.articlebody:
TWO cops smashed a car's window to save a dog baking in the sunshine on the back seat  only to find it was a £4.50 cuddly TOY.

The PC and WPC feared for the animal after being alerted by a passer-by.

They first tried to rouse the "sleeping" King Charles Spaniel.

When that failed, they decided to break a window of the smart Mercedes coupe  then realised their mistake when they picked up the lifelike plaything.

Owner Gordon Williams, 80, returned to find his car covered in glass and a note. It read: "Smashed your window re concern for animal on rear seat."

The force is now having to pay £180 compensation. Gordon said: "I guess they felt like idiots."

The retired mining engineer, of Mansfield, Notts, had left his motor in a public car park last Monday when temperatures soared to 18°C (64°F).

Widower Gordon said he bought the toy on holiday  and named him Little Willy.

He said: "He'd been living quite happily on the car's back seat. But I've decided he will be safer sleeping on a chair in my kitchen."

Nottinghamshire Police said: "Officers believed a dog could be suffering. This is a perfect example of why drivers need to think about what they leave on view."

pages.headline: Take dad
pages.teaser: SINGER completes amazing hat-trick after Gary and Robbie
pages.articlebody:
THRILLED Mark Owen has completed an amazing Take That hat-trick  by revealing he is the THIRD band member now expecting a kid.

Wife Emma Ferguson, 35, is carrying their third baby. Robbie Williams and Gary Barlow are also dads-to-be.

Mark revealed he was expecting his third child after his wife's baby bump grew too big to hide.

The pop star's missus quit trying to conceal her growing tum after passing the four-month stage of pregnancy.

Their happy news means three of the five-strong band are waiting to become dads, following recent announcements by Robbie Williams and Gary Barlow.

A close pal of Mark, 40, said last night: "He's over the moon.

"He was keeping it a secret for as long as possible so he could enjoy keeping the special news in the family. But now it's come to a point where it's time to share it with everyone."

Robbie, 38, and wife Ayda, 32, confirmed last Friday they are expecting their first child.

And The Sun revealed last month how X Factor judge Gary, 41, and missus Dawn, 42, were preparing for their fourth.

Mark's pal added: "The lads have had a right old giggle about the three of them having baby news about the same time.

"Gary was joking there must have been nothing on the telly a few months back for them all to get down to business."

Mark and Emma, 35, are already parents to Elwood Jack, six, and daughter Willow Rose, four.

The baby news is a sign their marriage is back on track.

The Sun revealed how the singer  now recording a new batch of solo songs  struggled with an alcohol problem and extra-marital affairs in 2009.

The pal added: "Mark and Emma have gone through a lot of soul-searching.

"Mark's turned his life around and proved to Emma that he is the man she fell in love with. Life really couldn't be better for them."

Gary was last night awaiting a rescue boat after being stranded on the Solomon Islands near Papua New Guinea, ahead of a forecast cyclone.

pages.subdeck: BLUE RED ... stunned Dalglish watches as fuming Carroll storms off pitch
pages.headline: It's a f****** joke, f*** off
pages.teaser: ANDY CARROLL launched an F-word rant at Liverpool boss Kenny Dalglish at Newcastle
pages.articlebody:
ANDY CARROLL launched an F-word rant at Liverpool boss Kenny Dalglish as his return to Newcastle turned into a nightmare.

The £35million misfit  also booked for diving  stormed down the tunnel without shaking Dalglish's hand after being hauled off in the 79th minute.

And to complete a miserable day for the Merseysiders, keeper Pepe Reina misses the FA Cup semi-final against Everton on April 14 following his red card for head-butting Toon defender James Perch.

Carroll could not contain his anger as he was taken off, screaming: "It's a f****** joke, f*** off' at Dalglish before disappearing down the tunnel while ripping off his shirt.

Earlier, he had also abused his former Toon boss Alan Pardew, who accused him of diving to try to win a penalty.

He shouted at Pardew: "I did not dive, you f****** c***."

Under-pressure Dalglish, who has taken Liverpool on their worst run for more than 50 years, said: "We don't have a problem with people showing their disappointment or frustration.

"But we need to channel it better than we have done.

"The frustration and disappointment were a result of the actions of Pepe and he got a deserved red card.

"Maybe they were feeling sorry for themselves.

"When Andy went off and up the tunnel, he was disappointed at the way the game had gone, not necessarily for himself but for the team."

Carroll had clashed with Pardew after tumbling in the area despite not being touched by keeper Tim Krul.

Krul fumed: "He dived. He just went over.

"I never touched him, so my reaction was to go straight up to him. He was looking for a penalty, like strikers like to do.

"But he didn't get it and the referee was at a good angle to see it was not a penalty."

Dalglish added: "We have no qualms about when Andy went down with their goalkeeper.

"It wasn't a penalty but I thought that Andy was losing his balance anyway."

Pardew was full of praise for his side and will insist they set their sights as high as him.

He said: "We have to see it home now. I want to take this club into Europe. Our fans deserve it and it will be a bit of a disappointment if we don't make it now."

pages.subdeck: Waste ... water surges into the road
pages.headline: We expose water company wasters
pages.teaser: A WATER firm is flushing MILLIONS of litres down the drain in the dead of night
pages.articlebody:
A WATER company is flushing MILLIONS of litres down the drain in the dead of night  while much of the country faces a hosepipe ban from Thursday.

Nearly 23million people will be hit by restrictions as most of the southern and eastern areas of the UK struggle with the driest spell for 86 years.

But while householders are told to take shorter showers and turn off taps when they clean their teeth, South East Water has been opening more than a thousand hydrants  letting water gush into the gutter at up to ten litres A SECOND.

The "flushing" operation has been going on since last September.

But a Sun investigation reveals that since New Year workers have been unleashing the cascades under cover of darkness around midnight.

More than FIVE MILLION litres  enough for 62,000 baths  went down the drain, according to figures seen by The Sun.

South East Water performs high-pressure flushing to clear mains pipes of sediment and rust.

But experts say the practice has few health benefits and has not been carried out on a large scale for years.

Sun reporters watched last Tuesday as two vans, belonging to South East Water and a contractor, stopped at a hydrant in a street in Bexhill-on-Sea, East Sussex, at 11.45pm.

Workers sent water surging into the road, checking a sample every few minutes for discolouration. The Sun saw the process repeated 20 times in dozens of streets that night. And more hydrants were opened on Thursday night.

Nearly 1,100 hydrants have been flushed since September in areas including Bexhill and Burwash, East Sussex, and Tunbridge Wells and Tonbridge, Kent.

South East Water supplies drinking water to 2.1million customers in Kent, Sussex, Surrey, Hampshire and Berkshire.

Like other companies it is introducing restrictions to combat the effects of an increasingly severe drought brought on by two abnormally dry winters.

The use of hosepipes for watering gardens, washing cars, filling ponds, cleaning patios and boats and filling swimming and paddling pools will be banned.

South East Water director Paul Seeley has already suggested on TV that people could take short showers instead of having a bath.

A drought report from the Environment Agency last week listed the company's Ardingly reservoir in West Sussex and Bewl Water reservoir on the Kent-East Sussex border as "exceptionally low".

A special order allows Ardingly to take water from dwindling river supplies. And it is expected that more will be pumped from the Lower Ouse, causing extra distress to fish and wildlife already suffering from low water levels.

One water industry worker said of the flushing: "It is morally wrong and even employees with 30 years' experience have been outraged."

South East Water said in a statement last night that flushing is due to finish this week.

But information passed to The Sun indicates there are plans for the work to continue for at least three weeks.

The statement added: "Flushing takes place during the night to ensure that there is less disruption to our customers.

"We are doing everything to save water during this time of drought. However we do need to occasionally flush our mains from start to finish to maintain the water quality.

"In Bexhill we received feedback about water discolouration so it was important that we carried out the work to ensure the system was running crystal clear."

But other water companies say they curb flushing operations in a drought.

Bristol Water says on its website: "If we were short of water, then flushing  even though it is important work  would be curtailed."

National drought co-ordinator Helen Vale said: "We expect water companies to do more to tackle leaks and continue their campaigns to encourage customers to use water wisely."

b.jackson@the-sun.co.uk

First leak table is revealed

WATCHDOGS have published the first leak league table  shaming Thames Water as Britain's worst offender.

Thames, the nation's biggest supplier with 8.8million customers, loses 665million litres EVERY DAY. That is 25.7 per cent of its daily input, says Ofwat.

The company, among those starting hosepipe bans, yesterday announced a 6.7 per cent price hike. It banked £600million last year.

Firms imposing hosepipe ban and total percentage of water input leaked per day: Thames 25.7%; Veolia Water Central 21.0%; Anglian 19.4%; Veolia Water Southeast 17.7%; South East 17.0%; Southern 16.0%; Sutton & East Surrey 15.1%.

Firms at medium risk of a ban: Severn Trent 26.8%; South West 19.7%; Bristol 18.1%; Cambridge 18.0%; Portsmouth 16.5%.

Blizzards on way to chill UK

FLAKY weather is set to start Britain shivering today  with SNOW forecast just days after the freak warm spell.

Up to two inches is expected in the North with blizzards possible in the South tomorrow.

After last week's 23°C (73°F) highs, temperatures might tumble to an icy -9°C (16°F).

The cold snap could catch the UK off guard as some councils took gritters off winter duty on Saturday.

Leeds and West Yorks will get snow tonight as it moves down from Scotland. The Midlands will be hit tomorrow morning, then the Home Counties. Flurries are also due on Wednesday.

Drought a threat to wildlife

BRITAIN'S wildlife could be decimated by the drought, Government conservation experts have warned.

Key wetland areas have dried out putting animals' and insects' natural habitats at risk.

Alastair Driver, of the Environment Agency, said: "The lack of water in water meadows, marshes and other wetlands has hit many species' breeding seasons. Mammals like water voles are particularly at risk as falling water levels expose their burrows so stoats and weasels can get in.

"One population at Hurst, Berkshire, is almost certain to go extinct this year."

pages.subdeck: Draw dropper ... Andy shows Warhol sketch he found in sale
pages.headline: £3 jumble sale sketch is £1.3million Warhol
pages.teaser: LUCKY Andy Fields picked up original made by Andy Warhol in famous style as a child
pages.articlebody:
LUCKY Andy Fields went to a humble jumble sale  and picked up an original Andy Warhol drawing worth £1.3MILLION.

The 1930s sketch, never previously seen in public, was hidden among a handful which art buff Andy bought for £3 in Las Vegas.

The signed work, on tattered paper, is thought to have been etched by art world legend Warhol when he was either ten or 11. Experts have hailed it the earliest known example of the late American's Pop Art  for which he became famous decades later.

And despite its formal valuation of £1.3million, dad-of-one Andy has been told it might be worth TEN times that.

But the businessman, from Tiverton, Devon, has no plans to sell. Instead he wants to put it on display for others to enjoy.

Andy, who found the drawing in 2010, said: "It's an incredibly important work. It redefines the work of one of the most famous artists of the last 100 years.

"It moves the birth of Pop Art back two decades, showing Warhol was already doing that sort of stuff at a far younger age.

"I'm not interested in the financial gain for now. It's only right that great art should be shared."

The figure in the drawing is 1930s singer and actor Rudy Vallee. The seller was a drug abuser who told Andy his aunt had been a carer for Warhol in his youth.

Andy spent weeks trying to find the man. He said: "I needed to find out everything he knew about it  but he'd vanished."

Warhol's Campbell's Soup Can (Tomato) sold for £5.6million in 2010. His piece Lemon Marilyn fetched £17.5million in 2007.

A video seen by The Sun shows Zaloumis in a yellow and black dress and headscarf, on stage lapping up applause and wolf whistles at the Miss Zambia UK 1998 pageant.

He came face-to-face with an intruder in his bathroom, locked himself in a bedroom and called police.

They found the woman lying on the top shelf of a walk-in wardrobe. Zaloumis, of Catford, South East London, is due to appear in court again in June.

But her half-brother, Jason Zaloumis, 36, insisted: "Leanne is not that kind of person. She is an upstanding, outstanding woman. She was brought up by a well-to-do father who doted on her. She had everything. None of us lacked for anything."

She comes from a prominent family. Her grandfather, a transport tycoon, was a member of the Zambian parliament and her aunt is a leading lawyer.

nibs.headline: Email spy war on paedos and terrorists
nibs.teaser: SNOOP plan 'focuses on everyone  not just criminals'
nibs.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
nibs.articlebody:
PLANS to allow GCHQ spies to monitor everyone's phone-calls, emails, texts and website visits were blasted yesterday.

Ministers said it will help target terrorists, organised crime and paedophiles.

But civil liberty groups and some MPs fiercely opposed the proposals last night.

Internet providers would have to install equipment to let GCHQ monitor the web and see who we contact, how often and for how long. They would still need a warrant if they want to read emails and texts.

But everyone could be monitored  not just those suspected of a crime. Tory MP David Davis said: "It is not focusing on terrorists or on criminals.

"It is absolutely everybody. Our freedom and privacy has been protected by using the courts by saying, 'If you want to intercept, if you want to look at something, fine. If it is a terrorist or a criminal, go and ask a magistrate and you'll get your approval.'

"You shouldn't go beyond that in a decent, civilised society, but that is what is being proposed."

Campaign group Liberty's director Shami Chakrabarti also condemned the idea. She said both the Tories and Lib Dems had opposed similar proposals when Labour was in power. She said: "This is more ambitious than anything done before. It is a pretty drastic step in a democracy.

"It was resisted under the last government. The coalition bound itself together in the language of civil liberties. Do they still mean it?"

Tory MP Margot James also voiced unease. She said: "I am sure there will be considerable pressure brought to bear as the proposals are debated for protections to be built in to protect people's privacy."

A Home Office spokesman said: "It is vital that police and security services are able to obtain communications data in certain circumstances to investigate serious crime and terrorism and to protect the public.

"We need to take action to maintain the continued availability of communications data as technology changes."

nibs.teaser: NOBEL Peace Prize winner could take office in military govt
nibs.articlebody:
FORMER Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi has won a landmark by-election in Burma.

The freedom fighter, imprisoned in her own home for 20 years by the former junta, could now take office in a largely military-run government.

Though her win will give her little say and not change the balance of power it will give hope to Burma's downtrodden masses.

Dancing supporters in the city of Yangon waved party flags, made victory signs and chanted: "We won! We won!" Shopkeeper Thien said: "It is the people's victory."

Results had to be confirmed last night as Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy Party claimed "rampant irregularities" with waxed ballot papers hindering vote counts.

Suu Kyi, 66  whose 1990 landslide win led to her detention  said that campaigning had been anything but fair. Voter Go Khehtay said: "I believe she will be able to bring real change."

Last year a long-standing military junta gave power to a civilian government  dominated by retired officers.

But President Thein Sein's authorities surprised the world with a wave of reforms.

The judging panel of coaches face away from the contestants on the new BBC1 talent series.

He added: "I'd never have done X Factor or Britain's Got Talent, but this was different to any other show. That crucial first impression is made just through your voice, not how you look, and that's what appealed to me."

David sang The Man Who Can't Be Moved by The Script, whose frontman Danny O'Donoghue is one of The Voice's four coaches.

pages.headline: House collapses after huge explosion
pages.teaser: RESCUE dog finds man trapped beneath rubble after early morning blast
pages.articlebody:
SIX people had to be rescued from a house this morning after it collapsed following a huge explosion.

Police and firefighters were called to the semi-detached property, divided into three flats, in Clacton, Essex, at about 2.30am following a suspected gas blast.

A family of four was rescued from the roof of the building and firefighters saved a woman and a man trapped under rubble from inside.

About 60 people were evacuated from nearby homes and an adjoining property is also believed to be unstable.

But it is thought that all residents have been accounted for by the Urban Search and Rescue Team.

Assistant Divisional Officer Martyn Hare said: "We believe there has been a gas explosion which has caused substantial collapse in a house which has been converted into flats.

"Firefighting operations are continuing at the scene. The road has been closed and neighbouring properties have been evacuated."

His colleague Neil Holloway added: "When crews arrived they were faced with a house which had almost totally collapsed.

"Four people had been led to safety and a woman was quickly rescued from the rear of the building.

"The Urban Search and Rescue Team quickly located a man trapped in the rubble and were able to safely rescue him.

"It is extremely lucky that no-one has died here and it is testament to the skill of firefighters and the search and rescue team that everyone has been rescued alive.

"Crews have been withdrawn from the rubble as firefighting operations continue.

"The fire is under the rubble and is proving hard to get to so I expect firefighting operations will continue for several hours."

Rescue dog Kirby, who qualified only last Thursday, found the man trapped under the rubble.

His handler Graham Currie said: "It took him less than a minute to locate the man in the rubble and we were able to speak to him to confirm his location.

"Then it was a matter of removing the rubble to rescue him. The man was conscious when we rescued him."

pages.subdeck: Jailed ... twisted killer Daniel Bartlam
pages.headline: Boy, 14, murdered mum with hammer in Corrie copycat killing
pages.teaser: TWISTED Daniel Bartlam, who was obsessed with soap killer John Stape, is jailed
pages.articlebody:
A TEENAGER who was obsessed with Coronation Street killer John Stape murdered his own mother in a horrific copycat hammer attack.

Daniel Bartlam, then 14, butchered mum Jacqueline Bartlam, 47, with a claw hammer as she slept  after watching the soap villain kill one of his victims the same way.

Bartlam, from Redhill, Notts, then doused her body in petrol and set it alight  before telling neighbours she had been killed by a burglar on Easter Monday last year, April 25.

At Nottingham Crown Court today, Bartlam, now 15, was jailed for a minimum of 16 years.

The court heard that the twisted teen had spent weeks plotting his mother's death  even going as far as to pen a play about a boy called Daniel who killed his mother and got away with murder.

On the night of the murder Daniel crept into his mother's bedroom, where she was sleeping with his brother Dominic, six.

He took two hammers, one of them a claw hammer, into his mother's room. He killed her and then poured petrol on the body and set it alight.

He removed his brother from the house, and began to tell neighbours what he would later tell police in interview  that an intruder had broken into the house and killed his mother and escaped out of a window.

But he was found guilty of murder after a trial earlier this year.

Speaking after the verdict, Detective Chief Inspector Kate Meynell, from Nottinghamshire Police said: "The level of violence, the degree of planning and the extent of his lies is not only shocking, but it's also chilling that a boy could do this.

"I've never dealt with something like this and I'm not aware of any other case in this country. He thought he could commit the perfect murder and get away with it."

The court heard how officers who searched the boy's room found violent drawings and writings, along with a claw hammer and a container of cleaning fluid.

They also discovered that websites he had looked up included "Man kills wife and makes it"; "How to get away with murder", and "People who get away with murder in shows".

Forensic examinations of his computer also found footage of violent scenes from Trial and Retribution, EastEnders, Hollyoaks, and Coronation Street  the latter including the Stape murder scene.

The court heard how Bartlam had also written the sick story in which he played the main character, someone who got away with rape and murder.

He described the character murdering a woman with a hammer and setting the house on fire.

He thought he had deleted the story completely before committing his crime  but experts recovered the file from his computer's auto save.

An ITV spokesman said: "ITV takes careful steps to ensure that pre-watershed drama is appropriate for a family audience, and the Stape murder scenes in Coronation Street were fully compliant."

In a statement, Jacqueline's parents said: "We find it so hard to explain what we are going through.

"There are no winners here because not only have we lost Jacqui, but we have lost Daniel too because of what he's done.

"We know it was the right result at court but trying to understand how a boy you have loved for 14 years can do something like this is so difficult.

"To find out that Daniel planned to kill his own mother and then hear all the details, it is all so hard to believe. The most difficult part for us and something that only Daniel can answer is 'why?'"

pages.headline: Sex monsters spared prison
pages.teaser: SEX beasts who have spent DECADES preying on victims are dodging prison terms
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
SEX beasts who have spent DECADES preying on victims are dodging prison terms, figures reveal.

Soft-touch judges are letting off serial offenders with community sentences or cautions.

Some of the sickos have dozens of previous convictions. Official statistics show two paedophiles  each with a 30-YEAR record of offences  were not jailed despite breaking the strict rules of the sex offenders register.

One already had 12 convictions for breaching the register's regulations while the other had ten. Both had been jailed in the past.Other figures show how even perverts convicted time and again of taking and publishing indecent photos of children are dodging prison.

One man who walked free had 29 previous convictions and another 27.

The Ministry of Justice statistics, published in a Parliamentary answer, will fuel fears that hardened criminals are side-stepping justice.

Philip Davies, Tory MP for Shipley, West Yorks, uncovered the figures. He said: "These are extremely serious offences committed by persistent, long-standing sex offenders  but they are not going to jail.

"Most people would think these men would be automatically jailed for breaching the sex offenders register, never mind breaching it for the 12th or 13th time. It is also shocking that people who take indecent photos of children  and who have been repeatedly convicted for doing so  are not being locked up."

A Ministry of Justice spokesman said: "Sexual offences are devastating for victims and tough penalties are available to the courts. These include sentences of up to life in prison for the most serious crimes.

"The latest statistics show that both the number of convictions for sexual offences and the average length of sentences handed down have increased significantly in the past year  and substantially over the past ten years."

The spokesman added: "Sentencing in individual cases is a matter for independent judges who make their decisions on the full facts of each case."

Depraved newsagent Lewis Knight, 60, has now been jailed for 15 years after being extradited and convicted of rape, indecent assault and gross indecency.

The city's MP Don Foster blasted the lax security that allowed Knight to flee to Barcelona before he was traced for his Bristol Crown Court trial.

pages.teaser: ELEVEN people incredibly survived as their aircraft went down in a snowy field shortly after takeoff
pages.articlebody:
A PASSENGER plane crashed shortly after taking off in Siberia this morning, killing 32 of the 43 people on board.

The 11 survivors are currently in hospital fighting for their lives.

The UTair aircraft was due to fly from Tyumen to the oil town of Surgut, Russia, with 39 passengers and four crew.

It went down on a snowy field just outside Tyumen, a major city which is home to many wealthy oil and gas companies. The cause of the crash remains unknown.

UTair published a list of the passengers and crew, and none of them appeared to be foreigners.

The Emergency Situations Ministry said 12 survivors were flown to a hospital by helicopter, but one of them died there.

Russia has seen a string of deadly crashes in recent years. Some have been blamed on the use of aging Soviet-era aircraft.

But industry experts have pointed to a number of other problems, including poor crew training, crumbling airports, lax government regulation and widespread neglect of safety in the pursuit of profits.

Pilot error was blamed for a crash in Yaroslavl, a city 150 miles north-east of Moscow, in September that killed 44 people, including a professional hockey team.

Pilot error and fog were also ruled the main causes of a crash in April 2010 that killed Poland's president and 95 other people as their plane was trying to land near Smolensk, western Russia.

THIS amazing footage shows a tow truck driver's miracle escape just moments before his vehicle plummeted off a mountain road into a ravine.

The footage, filmed by another motorist, shows the tow truck pulling a large articulated lorry along a precarious snowy mountain road.

Seconds later it tumbles over the edge of the flimsy metal barrier, flipping upside-down and pulling the tow truck down with it.

The driver is seen jumping to safety just as his truck is pulled over the edge and down the cliff as well.

The accident happened on Sunday afternoon in Leirosen, Norway.

The driver of the lorry was seriously injured, suffering several broken bones.

He is now said to be in a stable condition in hospital.

FUNNYMAN Justin Lee Collins denied harassing his ex-girlfriend when he appeared at court today.

The star of the Friday Night Project spoke only to plead not guilty and confirm his name during the 15-minute hearing.

The 37-year-old, dressed in a navy blue blazer with sky blue shirt, blue tie, blue jeans and flash maroon shoes, listened intently as the charges against him were read out

The long-haired Bristolian is accused of harassment by assaulting and threatening to assault Anna Larke between January 1 and August 1 last year.

A trial date was fixed for him to return to St Albans Crown Court, in Herts, in September.

Sonia Woodley, his defence counsel, said: "Due to the defendant's professional commitments September would be most convenient for him."

Judge John Plumstead told Lee Collins: "You will come back here for your trial.

"Between now and then you must stay out of touch with the people named in your previous bail terms."

He was bailed with the condition not to contact, directly or indirectly, Miss Larke or her family.

Collins, of Kew, West London, said nothing as he left the court and climbed into a dark green taxi.

His current girlfriend also declined to comment.

Stunning PC Alice Nicholas, 22, ditched her dowdy police helmet and donned a sparkly tiara to beat her 29 rivals and become the new Miss Cornwall on Friday.

She now hopes her entry into the competition will help inspire more young girls to join the force.

His comments come as tensions mount between the UK and Argentina.

This compares to just 29 in all of London's 32 other boroughs.

Andrew Boff, a London Assembly member and spokesman for the Conservative group on the 2012 Games, said: "This increased activity has happened disproportionately in the Olympic boroughs."

Mr Boff said he supported police action where local residents had complained about anti-social behaviour, but added he was worried authorities were "clamping down on prostitution without these complaints".

A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police said a team had been set up in 2010 to address vice-related crime in the Olympic boroughs.

Host nations are known to crack down on groups like prostitutes and the homeless ahead of the Olympics as hundreds of thousands of international visitors fly in for the event.

PANIC buying at the pumps has left Britain BETTER set for a fuel crisis, William Hague claimed yesterday.

The Foreign Secretary's incredible statement came after last week's closure of dozens of petrol stations amid chaos across the UK.

He declared: "The country is in a better state of preparedness now than it was a week ago for the eventuality of a tanker strike."

Unions and fuel firms will hold crunch talks today in a bid to avert a crippling stoppage  amid warnings that thousands of truckers could join the protests.

Mr Hague dismissed criticism of ministers such as Francis Maude who urged people to fill up jerry cans with petrol. He said: "I think they've handled that correctly." But he did admit that Mr Maude made a "technical error" by telling people to use jerry cans.

Health Secretary Andrew Lansley rubbished reports that Mr Maude was under pressure to quit after a woman suffered horrific burns while pouring petrol from a jerry can. PM David Cameron is hoping for a breakthrough in talks at conciliation service ACAS.

But one hauliers' leader Andrew Spence warned yesterday that up to 4,000 truckers were ready to back the tanker driversif they go on strike. His men plan to blockade refineries and cause gridlock on motorways to stop the Army from moving fuel around the UK.

One poll yesterday showed that four out of five Brits blame the Government for sparking last week's panic.

Labour leader Ed Miliband will today accuse ministers of deliberately triggering it to divert attention from the row over Tory donors.

Panic buying seems to be over. Sales of petrol and diesel fell on Friday and Saturday after Thursday's peak.

About 2,000 tanker drivers have threatened to strike over pay and safety concerns.

pages.articlebody:
A WRINKLE-busting pill that offers Factor 10 sun protection is on sale in the UK.

The skin supplement has already been available as a complexion-smoothing aid.

Now trials have proved it can also help the body produce its own shield against sun damage.

Colladeen Visage contains plant chemicals lutein and anthocyanidins, which help the body build a basic barrier against harmful rays.

Biochemist Dr Sam Christie, who reviewed three-month independent medical trials of the pill, said it could offer basic protection and improve the skin's appearance.

She said: "The study shows that Colladeen has proven, visible effects on the appearance of skin. This is thanks to the way it supports the structures beneath the skin's surface, including the main protein collagen."

She added: "Plants protect themselves from sun damage with pigments such as lutein and anthocyanidins. When these are present in high quantities in our diet we see a complex effect on skin chemistry: a natural SPF is achieved."

But she warned that fair-skinned people would still need to stay in the shade or use an SPF 50-plus cream.

Medics tested Colladeen in the same way as protective creams and lotions.

They found it strengthened small blood vessels that feed oxygen and nutrients to cells, strengthening the inner and outer layers of skin.

Initial trials on 60 men and women were carried out by the independent Aspen Laboratories in Maldon, Essex.

People who took the tablet daily for 12 weeks had an enhanced defence against sun damage. Further studies are planned.

The pills are £18 for a two-month supply.

By Emma Little, Health and Science Editor



A PILL is cheaper and less messy than sun cream  and blazes ahead as an easy-to-use form of protection.

But the SPF is low, and we are years away from replacing lotions with tablets.

Many of the pill's benefits can be replicated with the right diet. Coloured veg is packed with anthocyanidins and carotenoids. They improve blood flow and help protect the skin from sunlight damage  just like Colladeen.

pages.headline: Real King's Speech desk set goes under hammer
pages.teaser: WRITING set owned by stammering King George VI during declaration of war speech to go under the hammer
pages.articlebody:
THIS desk set could be the one that the stammering King George VI wrote his famous King's Speech on.

The set  which includes an ink well, letter rack, roller blotter, pen tray, paper knife, stamp box and blotter  was owned by the King when he wrote Britain's declaration of war on Germany and is now up for auction.

And it is believed that "Bertie"  played by Colin Firth in the 2010 film  used it to pen the poignant address to the nation in 1939.

The navy blue writing set had been a gift from the King's brother, Edward the Duke of Windsor, shortly after he abdicated and married divorcee Wallis Simpson.

It is engraved with the initials D & W  standing for David, the name King Edward went by, and Wallis.

Underneath is the message: "There, but for the grace of God..."

But the gilded set was so disliked by his wife, the Queen Mother, that she gave it away to a "titled lady" soon after her husband's death.

Neil Shuttleworth, from Specialist Auction Services, is selling the piece alongside 24 other royal related items.

He said: "I've never seen anything as wonderful as this piece.

"It has a rich and colourful history, spanning a rather poignant period of war-time in our nation's history.

"It was a time when King George would have written dozens of inspiring speeches, many of which he struggled to perform in front of the mic due to his speech impediment.

"If the story fits, then it is something which has played an integral part in history.

"It could well have been used by the King to write the speeches that inspired the now legendary film."

Eventually the set fell into the hands of an anonymous 70-year-old vendor, who has decided to auction it off - alerting Royalists and memorabilia collectors the world over.

Neil added: "In what is the Queen's Jubilee year, it is a very topical item.

"We are expecting international interest, and undoubtedly wealthy Royal enthusiasts both sides of the Atlantic will be looking to get their hands on this unique piece."

He added: "The desk set's colourful background alone makes it a very sellable item.

"We believe it was given to King George around May 1937 by his brother, soon after he had succeeded him.

"At this time the pair were on good terms, but that soon deteriorated, causing the Queen Mother to dislike the set because of its association with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, who contravened the Church of England by being divorced, something frowned upon at that time."

pages.articlebody:
A PRETTY marketing manager was left unrecognisable after a severe reaction to her iPhone case left her face covered in a bright red rash.

Brunette Jenny Taylor, 30, was also lumbered with a sticky yellow sore where she had held the handset to her ear.

The shock injuries which spread over her face and neck appeared after she fitted the cover on her mobile device.

Jenny went to hospital when her own mother failed to recognise her but was sent home with over-the-counter antihistamine tablets.

But the next morning her face had swelled so much she was unable to open her right eye and could barely swallow.

She returned to hospital where tests revealed she had developed 13 skin allergies.

Jenny, from Kirby, Liverpool, has now been warned she is allergic to dozens of household items including jeans, coins and door handles.

She said: "My neck looked like a roll of sausages and I knew I definitely needed to go back to the doctors.

"You could literally see the shape of where the phone had been on my face, lots of little spots came up in the same area.

"My mum didn't recognise me at first, she gasped in shock when she saw me, she was appalled.

"I couldn't swallow properly, so the doctors booked me in to another hospital and told me to go there straight away."

After suffering the reaction in November Jenny was referred to the dermatology clinic at Royal Liverpool University Hospital, where she underwent 140 patch tests on her skin.

Doctors suggested her allergies could have been triggered by the silicone in her Griffin FlexGrip Punch iPhone case.

Jenny, who lives with partner Chris Oswell, 32, said: "The doctors said that just because I hadn't had a reaction up to that point, it didn't mean that I wouldn't have one in the future.

"I'm super-careful and I do anything I can to avoid setting off my allergies.

Jenny bought the £16 cover through the Apple store.

She said: "I've contacted both Apple and Griffin to warn them about my allergic reaction but I haven't received any calls back or any letters.

"I just don't want this to happen to anyone else because it's put my life on hold."

The case manufacturer is yet to comment.

pages.headline: Tribes are at war with pop acts
pages.teaser: BAND say they plan to take on big budget artists with hard graft at Biz Session
pages.articlebody:
TRIBES are determined to prove the "old fashioned" approach to forging a career in music still works.

The Camden rockers peaked at No9 in the UK album chart when their debut collection Baby was released in January.

Despite pitting themselves against the commercial might of big budget pop acts, they believe intense touring and hard graft is the way forward for struggling British bands to reclaim their place in the mainstream.

After playing a three-song Biz Session, frontman Johnny Lloyd said: "Mumford & Sons and The Vaccines have been topping the charts in recent years.

"Our album went in at No9. There are still bands going in the top 10.

"Obviously pop acts have more money in their marketing budgets but you can overcome that with serious amounts of touring and hard work like old fashioned pop bands used to do.

"We've just got to keep on top of what we're doing and not worry about the future of the music industry."

Guitarist Dan White added: "I think that's why we've got to where we are now  through dedication, working really hard and our love for it.

"We love going around the country in our van, sleeping on floors."

And they're certainly not begrudging the lack of five-star hotel accommodation that was synonymous with the guitar group scene of the not-too-distant past.

Bassist Jim Cratchley said: "That's probably the biggest change in the music industry between now and four years ago.

"No one has a plane anymore, no one stays in hotels. You sleep on your mate's floor."

Johnny, Dan and Jim  minus drummer Miguel Demelo  performed their single We Were Children, Coming Of Age and a cover of Lady Gaga's You And I at their impressive session.

Tribes formed in 2010 and very quickly rocketed to prominence, supporting the Pixies "on our sixth gig, before we'd even made 10 quid".

Their album Baby draws heavily on singer Johnny's torment following the death of his pal Charles Haddon  the frontman of Ou Est Le Swimming Pool who committed suicide in 2010 in the backstage area of Belgium's Pukkelpop festival.

He also candidly references the collapse of his romance with an ex-girlfriend on several tracks.

Johnny said: "The album's not depressing but it's on the button of what was happening in my life.

"The Charlie stuff  like Corner Of An English Field and Nightdriving  was just looking back at our friendship.

"The break-up stuff was just the general mess of my love life at that time."

Although his personal woes provided Johnny with a focus when he was penning tunes for the record, he's adamant that songwriters don't need to be miserable to be at their best.

"I think you can write a song out of nowhere," he said.

"John Lennon proved that with many a track. But it is good to use your own experiences. It's easier because it's more believable for you."

In keeping with their traditional values, Tribes recorded the whole of Baby on tape  snubbing the popular trend of using computer technology.

Dan said: "We were sick of hearing so much music that was so obviously tweaked and tuned and cut up and made to sound perfect and polished.

"There's a lack of humanity to it. We wanted to make something that was inherently just four friends in a room together.

"Tape lends itself to that because you have to be at your best because it captures you naked. It was exhilarating.

"We got in there, got out and got back on the road."

And you can catch them on the road when they tour the UK in April and May.

BOYBAND One Direction have been labelled "the new Beatles" after they became the first British group to top the US charts with debut album Up All Night  something not even the Fab Four managed.

Sir Paul McCartney has even warned Niall Horan, Harry Styles, Louis Tomlinson, Liam Payne and Zayn Malik not to let the comparison with his legendary band become a "kiss of death".

Here the Professor of Pop, DJ Paul Gambaccini, explains why X Factor finalists 1D's real achievements should not be overlooked even though comparisons with The Beatles are over the top.

ONE DIRECTION have achieved something that no previous British boyband have even come close to  a debut No1 album in America.

People are inevitably comparing the welcome they have received in the USA to Beatlemania.

When John, Paul, George and Ringo first landed at Kennedy Airport in 1964, there were 3,000 screaming teens waiting for them.

There has certainly been lots of screaming for 1D and even some girls requiring medical treatment.

But we'll never see genuine Beatlemania again.

People who are trying to compare them dwell on the fact that One Direction are the first British group to enter the US album chart at No1.

This overlooks the fact that NO album entered the American chart at No1 until 1975.

Elton John was the first and second person to do it and Stevie Wonder was the third.

When somebody says: "One Direction  the biggest since the Beatles", I go: "Yeah, right! Show me the five big hits at 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 in the US charts."

However, 1D have achieved something incredible with their album and the speed of their success.

What makes their achievement even more jaw-dropping is that they have got this level of success in America without a huge single under their belts.

That is only possible now because of the power of social media. We've seen a similar thing with the film The Hunger Games.

In both cases people have heard about them through friends  so they feel like they have ownership.

The seeds were cleverly planted by Simon Cowell and his SYCO record label for 1D and the film company for The Hunger Games.

There was also a gap to fill. Every generation needs its own fresh pop experience. America was ready for a boyband and they didn't have one of their own.

Now they have fallen in love with not one but two British boybands at once.

Rivals The Wanted have peaked at No2 in the singles chart in America with Glad You Came.

But The Wanted must be furious that One Direction timed it slightly better. Neither group could have predicted how much appetite there is for a new boyband.

The only other acts filling the pop void are teen, or tween, performers like Justin Bieber.

When I say boyband, we are talking about the generation of boy groups who started in the Nineties. We think of Take That and Westlife as world famous but they never came close to cracking America.

None of them had a No1 album there. So, for 1D to achieve the No1 is an incredible achievement.

America has loved many British rock groups  the Stones, Coldplay, The Kinks and The Who and, of course The Beatles.

It has also loved many of its own boybands, from The Monkees to 'N Sync and Backstreet Boys.

Previously, the peak achievement by a British boyband was 5ive with their self-titled album in 1998  it was No27.

The highest position Take That ever reached was 69, although they did have one Top Ten single  Back For Good  which got to No7. Westlife peaked at 129 in the US album chart.

Even when Robbie Williams left Take That and became a huge star across the world, he remained relatively unknown in the US.

Screaming is nothing new now. But even in 1964 it was not new. Teen hysteria began with Frank Sinatra in the 1940s. It happens once every ten years or so. It happened with Elvis in the Fifties, then with the Osmonds, Jackson Five, David Cassidy.

They have all made good music.

But what they all share in common is that they satisfy the raging hormones.

At the moment, for whatever reason, 1D are satisfying a lot of American hormones.



Macca: Keep your identity



By LEIGH HOLMWOOD

SIR Paul McCartney has warned One Direction that being compared to The Beatles is the "kiss of death".

The crazy scenes of screaming fans as 1D tour the US and Canada have been compared to the Beatlemania of 1964 when Paul, John Lennon, Ringo Starr and George Harrison first hit North America.

But Sir Paul, 69, said the lads should be wary of any comparisons with the Fab Four as the pressure could get too much for them.

And he cited the example of Oasis  who were also compared to The Beatles  of what can go wrong.

He said: "It is the kiss of death. There are so many bands who all get called 'the next Beatles'.

"Suddenly it puts an awful lot of pressure on them to be the next Beatles.

"Oasis were 'the next Beatles' once. It's a pressure, because suddenly you've got to live up to all the things that we did, and it was a different time."

But he revealed he is a fan of One Direction  and wished the boys luck.

He told ITV1's Daybreak: "Let's just call them the next terrific band. Doing well in America  good luck lads."

pages.teaser: RUPERT Grint and Tom Felton among the actors at the grand opening of the Warner Brothers Studio Tour
pages.articlebody:
HARRY Potter stars turned out today at the red carpet opening of a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the blockbuster film series.

Rupert Grint, Tom Felton and Bonnie Wright were among the actors at the grand opening of the Warner Brothers Studio Tour - The Making of Harry Potter.

Hundreds of screaming Potter fans waited outside the studios in Leavesden, near Watford, Hertfordshire, where all eight of the multi-million pound grossing films inspired by JK Rowling's magical stories were shot.

Local boy Rupert - who played Ron Weasley - said: "This is the most glamorous I have ever seen Watford. It's exciting for everyone to see.

"There are so many memories in there and to share them with everyone is great. There are so many highlights but the model of the castle is out of this world."

The 23-year-old added that he had sneaked out some mementos for himself, including the number from Harry's door in Privet Drive. He said: "You can buy them from most DIY stores, and they've replaced it now."

The three-hour walking tour's attractions include the original Great Hall of Hogwarts School, built for Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone.

The hall features graffiti by Hogwarts' pupils, solid oak and pine house tables which were built for the films, and York stone flooring laid more than 11 years ago.

Some of the most iconic sets include Dumbledore's office, Diagon Alley, the Ministry of Magic, 4 Privet Drive, the Gryffindor common room and the Weasley kitchen.

Tom, who played bad-boy Draco Malfoy, said: "It's hard to sum it all up in a sentence but I will never forget walking through the Great Hall for the first time.

"It was just as magical now as it was all those years ago."

Visitors can get up close to the costumes, animatronics, special effects and props used throughout the Potter series and seen by millions on TV and movie screens worldwide.

Sarah Roots, vice president of the Warner Bros Studio Tour, said: "What makes this tour so special is that everything on show has been used in the making of the Harry Potter film series.

"All the sets, props and costumes are authentic and show the incredible detail and craftsmanship that goes into film production.

"All the films were shot at Leavesden so it's wonderful to be giving the sets a permanent home here."

A family ticket for two adults and two children will set them back £83.

Individual tickets for people 16 and over are £28 and £21 for children aged five to 15.

pages.headline: There is no secret to being a sex symbol. I play the game, that's all
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD siren and Transformers star MEGAN FOX on family, fame and films
pages.articlebody:
MEGAN FOX has become one of the world's hottest sex symbols, thanks to hit movies such as Transformers and Jennifer's Body.

She will next be seen  playing herself  in Sacha Baron Cohen's latest film, The Dictator, released on May 11.

Megan, 25, married her long-term boyfriend, 38-year-old actor Brian Austin Green, in 2010 and there are now reports she is pregnant.

Here she speaks to GARTH PEARCE about what her mother taught her.

MY mum Darlene taught me to fight for what I believe. She was strict, but wanted a daughter who could look after herself.

I was not the easiest of girls to bring up. From very young I seemed to know what I wanted to do in life  singing, dancing, acting.

It meant my mum had to drive for miles to take me to various classes. She was always encouraging about self-improvement.

She took me to auditions in Los Angeles, which was on the other side of the country from where we lived in Florida.

I was born in Oak Ridge, a small town in Tennessee, but was brought up mostly in St Petersburg, Florida, after my mother remarried.

When she and Dad were together, they did not have much money. But I was happy as a kid.

It made me realise you don't have to be rich to be happy. My dad used to hunt ducks and my mum would put them in the pot. We lived modestly.

My mum says I was born really ballsy. She's put up with it very well.

I attended a Pentecostal church and then a Christian school. I had to obey strict rules at school and at home. I was grounded a lot.

I got a diploma from a correspondence programme. It was the deal I made with my mum. I had to have a real diploma before she would allow me to drop out of Christian school and move to Los Angeles.

There have been some struggles along the way, which my mum has seen me through. I am also not the easiest of people to be friends with.

I think it is my fault. I work away from home and have learned to be on my own.

I don't socialise much on a film set and don't have to become best friends with the people I work with.

There is a saying in Hollywood that what happens on a film set stays on a film set. But if I'd ever dated a co-star, it would have been downright depressing. Most actors would not appeal to most women, if they actually met them.

I met Brian when I was 18. I was too young to remember his show, Beverly Hills 90210, so I didn't know who he was. But I knew I was instantly in love.

There is no secret to being a sex symbol. I play the game, that's all.

If people want to think of me as wild and crazy, that's up to them. The fact is, I've only had two serious boyfriends in my life  and I married one.

I have the same hang-ups as any other girl. Am I too fat? Too thin? Do I wear the right clothes? You think about it so much, it can hurt how you live.

So am I insecure? God, yes. Show me a woman who says she's totally secure about everything in her life and I will show you a pain in the ass.

There have been some bad moments along the way, during which calls to my mum have meant a lot.

I lived in New York, doing TV comedy Hope & Faith, and it was cold and miserable.

I was either at work or home in a little apartment, on my own. I let whole days slip by, doing nothing.

I am confident in how I project myself but not in terms of how I look. It all came to a head when I was making 2008 film How To Lose Friends And Alienate People in London.

There was one scene in which I danced around in lingerie. I suddenly felt like I couldn't do the scene and asked if I could wear a skirt.

The director, quite rightly, said it would look ridiculous.

But I was not happy. It ended up with the producer serving me a beer before the scene. I was tired from working non-stop on several films, was suffering from jet lag on the trip to England and started to worry about my ability.

That's where Mum comes in. I called her a few times from London and she was able to calm me down and encourage me.

I am still her little girl, whatever way you want to look at it.

pages.headline: Fitness blitz that beats 1hour slog
pages.teaser: DOING as little as four minutes  or one 'HIT'  can be better for you than an hour's slog. See how here
pages.articlebody:
LESS is more when it comes to working out. Doing as little as four minutes  or one "HIT"  can be better for you than an hour's slog.

The four-minute, high-intensity training session can increase your aerobic and anaerobic capacity and speed up the metabolism, helping you burn more fat and make you look 200 per cent leaner than a traditional 60-minute aerobic workout.

Known as the closest thing we have to a fitness miracle, the HIT workout is loved by researchers and fitness pros alike for its fat-torching abilities and simplicity.

Celeb fans include Jessica Biel and Cameron Diaz.

HIT workouts are not easy, but are appealing to time-starved mums, working women and anyone juggling a hectic life.

Sun fitness expert Nicki Waterman says: "My advice is to combine your plan with 30 minutes of aerobic exercise like fast walking, jogging, swimming, cycling or dancing, for example, to get the maximum effect.

"To do a HIT, simply pick an exercise and set a timer for 20 seconds on and ten seconds rest.

"Do the exercise as hard as you possibly can for 20 seconds and then rest for ten, repeating eight to 20 times in total. And remember, you have to work to 100 per cent maximum intensity. By the end of the four minutes you should feel like you've done a full workout and have nothing else to give."

Check out my favourites to get you started for one week.

But please check with your doctor before starting this exercise programme. And always warm up and cool down for at least five minutes before and after each HIT session.

MONDAY: Skipping

CARDIO and coordination all in one. Take a skipping rope and jump as fast as you can, using whichever foot pattern you like.

Options include both feet together, high knees, the "boxer shuffle" with heels in front, alternating feet, and butt-kickers.

Tip: Make sure your rope is long enough before you start  nothing ruins a good HIT workout like getting whipped across your calves.

To check for proper length, stand in the centre of your rope and pull the handles straight up. They should come at least as high as your armpits.

TUESDAY: Jumping Lunges

You already know and love (to hate?) lunges for their butt-blasting ability. Add a jump in between alternating legs to up the difficulty and cardio factor.

Start by stepping your right foot forward into a deep lunge, until your leg is parallel with the ground. Then jump, bringing your back (left) foot forward and landing in a lunge.

Tip: You can step through each lunge if jumping gets too hard.

WEDNESDAY: Box Jumps

Find a weight bench, or a step that hits somewhere between your shins and your knees.

Stand in front of it and jump on top of the bench/step with both feet together.

Jump back to the floor, again with both feet together. Try not to rest when you land and jump right back up again.

If this is too difficult, you can do step-ups onto the box instead.

THURSDAY: Mountain Climbers

Make a triangle with your hands and feet on the floor with your butt up in the air. Bring one leg towards your chest. Keeping hands on the ground, jump to switch your legs.

Tip: Just quickly touch each toe down so you're not resting by putting whole foot down.

FRIDAY: Hindu Squats

These are similar to a traditional squat but instead of stopping when your thighs are parallel to the ground, you continue down, dropping your butt towards your heels until your fingertips brush the ground.

Going through the full range of motion gets your heart rate up faster and engages more muscles.

Tip: Don't be afraid  contrary to popular belief, researchers now say that for healthy people, squatting to the ground won't hurt your knees.

SATURDAY: Bicycle Sprints

Bikes are perfect for engaging your whole lower body and really getting your heart rate up for those 20 seconds.

Tip: It's a little easier to time and to rest on a stationary bike  you can just take your feet off the pedals for ten seconds rather than trying to start and stop/coast on the road.

The HIT diet plan

SUN nutritionist Amanda Ursell says: "If your aim is to lose weight, then you need to combine your workout with a style of eating that provides energy to exercise, yet cuts empty calories that are keeping your body mass index high.

"Timing of your meals and snacks is especially important because your body needs fuel to cope with the HIT workout before you start and, once you have finished, to allow your muscles to recover and be ready for the next hard session.

"Here's how to eat to lose weight but keep your body healthy and able to cope with the HIT plan over the coming week."

Before you train: Whether you train before breakfast, before lunch or at the end of the day before dinner, have something like a handful of raisins, a banana or even a small smoothie an hour to 30 minutes before you start.

During training: Drink "to thirst". This simply means have a drink when you feel the need and stop once you no longer feel thirsty.

After training: Have your meal whether it is breakfast, lunch or dinner within half an hour of finishing. If you can't manage this, have another small snack like some dried fruit or a cereal bar.

YOUR DAILY DIET

Breakfast: This is not the week to skip breakfast, however rushed your daily schedule.

If you are training early, have breakfast once you have finished. If not, make time to have it before you leave the house.

Have a breakfast of porridge made with skimmed or semi-skimmed milk with some dried fruit such as chopped apricots; a wholegrain cereal such as Oatibix or Weetabix or a fruit salad which includes a banana with some zero per cent fat Total Greek yoghurt and a handful of sunflower seeds.

Alternatively, have two poached or boiled eggs with two pieces of toast and a glass of orange or apple juice.

Have a glass of water and your usual cup of tea or coffee using skimmed milk.

Mid-morning: Have a handful of nuts such as almonds, cashews, pistachios or Brazil nuts with an apple, orange or a pear and a glass of water.

Lunch: Build your lunch around an average-sized portion of carbohydrate foods that give you a steady supply of energy. These include pitta breads, tortilla wraps, bread, pasta, noodles, or a baked potato.

To these add some protein-rich food such as tuna, chicken, turkey, lean slices of roast beef, hard-boiled eggs, prawns, cottage or ricotta cheese, pulses such as baked beans, peas or lentils, tofu or Quorn products.

Have some veg with these such as tomato and cucumber in a sandwich, lettuce and spring onions in a wrap or pitta or salad with a baked potato and baked beans. Always have some water with your lunch.

Mid-afternoon: A couple of oat cakes with some cottage or ricotta cheese and berries; a slice of peanut butter on toast; an apple with a small matchbox-size piece of reduced-fat Cheddar or a handful of mixed nuts and raisins.

Dinner: As with lunchtime, dinner needs to be a mix of an average-size serving of carbohydrate-based foods such as new boiled potatoes, pasta, rice or noodles.

To these add some protein-rich foods such as lean red meat  lean mince, a lean pork chop or lean roast lamb; Turkey, chicken or ham; grilled, baked or canned fish; tofu, Quorn mince or "chicken" pieces, pulses such as baked beans.

Also add some vegetables. Broccoli, carrots, cauliflower, green beans, sweetcorn, tomatoes, onions  whichever you enjoy and find easy to prepare.

pages.teaser: SHE doesn't care if her date is rich, handsome or charming  as long as he's not single
pages.articlebody:
SELECTING a slinky dress for her night out, Dee Jones doesn't care if her date is rich, handsome or charming  as long as he's married.

For the past three months, the 33-year-old accountant has been dating attached men  and has no plans to change her ways.

Feeling no guilt, she is unrepentant when it comes to her playgirl lifestyle filled with gifts, lavish meals and no-strings sex.

Here Dee, from Harrow, North London, reveals why she thinks the wives of the married men she dates should be THANKING her rather than feeling angry with her.

Dee says: "There is nothing wrong with what I do. The way I see it, I'm helping the women because the men go home happier. I provide an emotional outlet for men bored by their wives."

In fact, she jokingly refers to herself as "an alternative marriage counsellor".

She continues: "As well as satisfying them, I also give the men advice on their failing personal lives. I love the excitement of doing something I shouldn't.

"And, what's even better is I can hand them back to their wives when I'm done."

A "feisty" woman who has never had a problem getting a date, Dee first went out with a taken man about four years ago.

She recalls: "I enjoyed my time with him and, although it came to an end, it didn't put me off.

"I loved the fact I could be with him when it suited me and I didn't have to be exclusively with him."

Finding herself single again in January after a long-term relationship, Dee decided she was going to hunt down more married men to get some excitement back in her life.

She says: "I just wanted some fun  so I typed 'meet a married man' into an internet search engine."

Within minutes, Dee had created an online profile on the website Illicit Encounters and was receiving loads of requests for dates.

She says: "It is so flattering and exciting. I love knowing that all these men want is to take me out and ravish me."

With no baggage, no strings and no emotional involvement, Dee could have her cake and eat it  at the expense of somebody else.

Shockingly, these types of websites actually facilitate affairs for people who are unhappy in their sex-less relationships but have no intention of leaving their partner.

Career girl Dee is currently seeing three married men "on rotation".

She explains: "Once a fortnight, the men will take me out to posh restaurants or for drinks in swanky bars  I even cook dinner for one of them at my house."

Amazingly, Dee doesn't feel any guilt.

She says: "They are the ones cheating, not me. I have spent all of my adult life in relationships where I have to think about the other person. I deserve time when I only have to think of myself  I am too independent to be in a relationship at the moment."

Naturally, most people who use the site do so in secret. She says: "I find it safer to keep phone contact to a minimum. I don't want anyone's wife to find out.

"I wait for them to contact me  then I know it is safe to reply."

Dee feels this type of dating is particularly good because she gets treated like a princess.

She says: "I get taken to top restaurants and many of the men buy me elaborate gifts  one guy bought me a TV and DVD player. But most importantly, I get showered with affection.

"Ultimately, after a few dates, the evening out will result in sex. If a guy calls and I'm not in the mood, I say so. If, by the end of the date, I want to invite them in, that's my prerogative. I'm totally in control and I love that."

Dee isn't physical with all of them  some men she "helps" just want to talk to her. In fact, she has stayed in steady contact with one man since November but knows she will never meet him.

"We are having an email affair, if there is such a thing," she explains.

"He and I both know that we will never meet due to distance but this suits us both  we flirt and chat online.

"There is obviously something missing in his life that I fill. I am happy to oblige  he is very sweet to me."

Although the majority of her dating experiences have been good, there have been some disastrous ones too.

She says: "It's always a nightmare when they fall in love with you. One guy declared that I belonged to him after only two dates.

"He told me that I wasn't allowed to date or flirt with any other men  hypocritical as he had a wife at home. I ended that quickly."

Dee admits she likes Illicit Encounters because of the upwardly mobile men that the site claims to attract. She says: "On the whole, all of the users are in well-paid jobs.

"The calibre of males I am meeting is certainly what makes me go back for more. They are all well-groomed and sophisticated. Who wouldn't want to be showered with gifts and shown a luxurious lifestyle?"

Asked if she ever gets attached to the men she sleeps with, the answer is a firm no. "I just switch off. I make my intentions clear from the start and once the guidelines are set, there's no going back."

Dee makes extramarital affairs look easy, but they do come with risks.

She says: "All of these men have children and some have been caught out, "It may sound stupid, but I actually think most of the wives involved just turn a blind eye to their husband's infidelity. They have a lifestyle they want to protect.

"Many have the car, the home, the children, the holidays. If they finished the relationship, they would risk losing all that.

"There is nothing more exciting than knowing I'll get to flirt over a candlelit dinner or secretly hold hands in the cinema.

"I know most people think this is all about sex, but it isn't. Despite what people assume, there is an emotional connection and we do think of each other. I wouldn't sleep with just anyone.

"Since I initially logged on, I have only been on dates with around 12 men in total  I am still fussy.

"In a nutshell, I am a bubbly and outgoing woman who loves attention but doesn't want a relationship  this type of lifestyle is tailor-made for me!"

But this isn't a life that Dee will continue with forever.

She says: "I'll stay on the site for a year or so then make a decision about what I want from there. I'm going travelling at Christmas, so it suits me to have another six months of no-strings fun."

Dee describes her last three months as "feeling like a kid in a sweet shop".

She explains: "I'm addicted to the thrill of it. I've found that some of the men are separated but not divorced yet. I'm not interested in them, it's not exciting enough. I go for the ones who are still married."

Asked how she would feel if her future husband cheated on her, she chuckles: "Of course I'd be upset, but there's no way I'll ever conform  that's just the way I am."

pages.articlebody:
SUPER-SLIM size six Victoria Beckham reckons she represents the average woman.

That may come as a shock to the UK's real-life average-sized women  who are a more shapely size 16.

Known for her figure-hugging dresses and barely there bikinis, it's no wonder that most women might not share the 37-year-old star's same sense of fashion.

pages.teaser: FIANCÉ left devastated as Jemma Webb loses battle with cancer on her big day
pages.articlebody:
A TRAGIC cancer sufferer died just 90 minutes before she was due to marry her fiancé.

Jemma Webb, 32, planned to wed sweetheart Alex Bradford next month but the date was brought forward as her condition worsened.

They were due to tie the knot at 4.30pm last Saturday  but she passed away at 3pm.

Her devastated fiance and parents yesterday paid tribute to Jemma, who inspired many other women to fight ovarian cancer.

Alex, 30, added: "On the day she was obviously excited and I was too.

"But by 2pm she got worse and within an hour she had passed away.

"She just kept herself together all through the illness. Some people give up, but she always thought she was going to beat it.

"Jemma may have had cancer, but cancer never had Jemma. Everyone was in awe for what she did and how she handled the cancer."

Jemma, of Exeter, Devon, first displayed symptoms in 2008 and started what was to be four years of chemotherapy in February 2010.

She worked with Alex at EDF Energy in Exeter and they became an item just nine months before her death.

Heartbroken Alex said he had no idea she had cancer when they first got together.

He explained: "I didn't know she was ill, you wouldn't.

"It was just a normal relationship as you could imagine to start with, but then two months in the cancer spread to her liver and her lungs and I knew then that I had to be there for her.

"But I loved her  it was as simple as that, so it was never really a decision."

Alex proposed in January and the wedding was set for April 18 at Colehayes Park, a Grade II listed Georgian mansion in Dartmoor National Park.

Forward

But on March 16 the couple decided to bring the date forward to the following day because Jemma's health was deteriorating.

They arranged for a special licence for a registrar to come to the family home and conduct the ceremony at 4.30pm on March 17.

But Jemma died at 3pm with Alex and her family at her bedside.

Mum Janet said her daughter worked hard to raise the profile of the Eve Appeal, which raises money for research into women's cancer.

Janet also told how Jemma also tackled the Great West Run, Birmingham Half Marathon, and even took part in the Race for Life the weekend after she had undergone chemotherapy.

She said: "She was inspirational  she carried on as if there was going to be every tomorrow.

"She was completely wiped out after the Race for Life but she was determined to do it."

She added: "She touched everyone she came in contact with and she lived life to the full and never gave up.

"She was determined to get across the message to younger women about the dangers of ovarian cancer, which they call the silent killer.

"We cared for her at home but it wasn't really care because she did it herself, she was very independent."

Dad Bob added: "She was absolutely unique.

"The week she died I helped her do her bedroom  she was always looking forward and never back.

"She never once let her dress drop, she never once let her make up drop, she never let her hair go silly, she never felt sorry for herself and always thought of other people before herself."

He added: "At her funeral there was about four times the church outside and inside, they had to do it by a loudspeaker."

Inspiration

Jemma had proven an inspiration to many women and her campaign for the Eve Appeal gynaecological cancer research charity was widely praised.

The charity said she had helped get the message to thousands of women.

Liz Engel, of the Eve Appeal, said: "I first came into contact with Jemma in 2009 when she wrote to me about her illness and was concerned that most of the people she knew were not aware of the risks or symptoms associated with ovarian cancer.

"Despite living with the worry and uncertainty of her diagnosis she was unwavering in her determination to help us to reach others, and particularly younger women like herself.

"There must have been days when she just didn't feel like it but whenever we asked her she would cheerfully agree."

Jemma's funeral was on Tuesday, March 27.

She was treated for ovarian cancer after her diagnosis in 2008.

Jemma first noticed something was wrong in 2008. She underwent surgery and started what was to be four years of chemotherapy in February 2010.

pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined women-only gym Curves and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."
