THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

pages.subdeck: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents
pages.headline: Renee's European parents
pages.teaser: ACTRESS Renee Zellweger reveals how her Norwegian mother influenced her career
pages.articlebody:
RENEE ZELLWEGER became a star thanks to her role opposite Tom Cruise in 1996 hit movie Jerry Maguire.

She is now established as one of the best-known and most highly paid actresses in Hollywood.

She won an Oscar for her role in the drama Cold Mountain and is famous for two films playing Bridget Jones.

Renee, 42, who had a short-lived marriage to singer Kenny Chesney in 2005, lives alone.

Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE about the influence her Norwegian-born mum Kjellfrid has had on her.

I DIDN'T grow up in a house where Mum focused on appearances. I don't remember her ever saying, "Wouldn't you be pretty if you did this or that?"

She never focused on anything beyond wanting me to be presentable  just well-groomed.

She wanted me to take care of myself and be healthy.

She did ask one or two questions when I became a cheerleader at high school because I would be teasing my hair and wearing lipstick and eyeliner.

I have an affiliation with a lot of countries. My mum was from Norway, my dad from Switzerland and my grandmother was Finnish, I have an Italian uncle, my first love was from South Africa and I was born in Texas.

I am definitely a Texan girl. It is a culture you really love in a Latin sort of way. You taste it and hear it and the climate is hot  Texas hot.

I felt lucky that my parents were European  different  and opened the doors to let me see America is not the centre of the universe.

It meant that, with Bridget Jones, I could go to London and enjoy all things English that make the country so wonderful.

During the making of the first film, I was even whistling songs by the Spice Girls.

But my mum was a realist about bringing up a teenage girl in America and kept a sense of humour.

She taught me that there are consequences for the things you say and do. She wanted me to grow up to be a good person. She and Dad liked simple and quiet. We had a very quiet house.

My mum didn't talk about her childhood growing up in Norway during the Second World War. Her sisters talked but all had difficulty in putting into words what they had seen.

They told about women giving birth in tunnels because there was no safe haven in any other structure.

And about being lost from family members and not being sure if they were alive.

So it was different for me, from my friends, growing up in a house where your mother was grateful just to have peace.

There was one thing which was never acceptable, though.

When I said: "I don't know how to do that", she would say: "Learn."

She encouraged me to get a college education (Renee has an English degree) as something to fall back on if acting didn't work out.

I moved to Los Angeles on December 6, 1993, to be exact.

My attitude was that I was going to see where it took me.

I had been working in Texas from the age of 21, and been in a couple of films. But I had pretty well exhausted my learning opportunities.

So I took a grungy little one-bed apartment and was scared to death of the future. It was a leap of faith, I guess.

I had some friends in LA who I had met on films but inside and emotionally, I felt alone.

To make a living, I worked in a bar called The Three Cubs on a street called Vine, behind the Mobil gas station.

It was an incredible place for a girl like me, who had lived in relatively safe places all her life.

There were crack deals being done on the street corners  so I would come back from the bar late at night then not be able to get out of my car to my apartment until the deals were completed.

I worked at the bar for two years. That was why Mum's guidance was so important and I stayed happy.

When you can take care of yourself and see your friends, that is all that matters.

The main difference that the film Jerry Maguire made in my life was I could pay my rent and didn't have to waitress any more. It gave me freedom.

I knew from the start that if I failed in acting, I always had my degree and could try a million things. I was not a "look at me" kind of girl.

I had gravitated toward acting because I had a vivid imagination and daydreamed a lot.

But I did not daydream about being on a film set, winning an Oscar or having people know my name.

I am grateful for the fact my mum never worried that I would compromise myself.

She was always telling me, 'You don't sit down enough'  but she learned to trust my instincts.

pages.subdeck: Tiring role ... Hollyoaks actress Holly Weston
pages.headline: Filming coma scenes put me in a deep sleep
pages.teaser: HOLLY Weston reveals she struggled with hospital scenes  because she kept dozing off
pages.articlebody:
HOLLYOAKS' Holly Weston struggled with dramatic hospital scenes  because she kept dozing off.

Her wild child character Ash Kane was left in a coma after being struck down with deadly meningitis.

But while the plot twist had viewers on the edge of their seats, Holly admits her biggest challenge was staying awake during filming.

The actress, who is pals with Madonna, said: "The coma bit is much harder than you think. I expected it to be so easy, just lying there all day. But it's really hard to lie straight and actually stay awake and know what is going on.

"I'd drop off and suddenly wake up and think 'Oh my God, I'm in the middle of a scene'."

Holly, whose screen alter ego is now on the mend, was befriended by the Queen Of Pop after being directed by her in 2008 film Filth And Wisdom. But while she has partied with Madge and her A-lister mates, Holly says she couldn't cope with Ash's booze-fuelled lifestyle.

She said: "I do like to go out and have a good time, but it is probably about once a month. Ash seems to be out all the time.

"I'm more happy sitting at home in front of the telly. I get horrendous hangovers, so I have to put aside a whole day to recover."

Holly is also good mates with co-star Jorgie Porter, who plays Theresa McQueen in the hit Channel 4 soap.

She was gutted Jorgie didn't win Dancing On Ice after she and partner Matt Evers were pipped at the post by Emmerdale's Matthew Wolfenden in last weekend's final.

Holly said: "Jorgie should have won. I have done dance classes with her and she's a brilliant ballet dancer. I kept telling her she would win. I'm a bit gutted she didn't but she did really well, she was amazing.

"Jorgie really enjoyed doing it. She would come in to work and was really positive about the experience."

While Holly gets on well with all her co-stars, she's relieved Ash hasn't been getting too close to any of them recently.

Holly said: "I did a lot of kissing scenes when I started, like in the toilet with Riley. But I haven't had any romantic situations for a while. Maybe it is time for Ash to have another romance.

"It is always a bit awkward. It's easier when you are new as you don't know people as well, but when you are really good friends with them and suddenly have to snog them it is a bit weird.

"I'm not missing doing those scenes."

pages.articlebody:
THE Voice star Barbara Bryceland had a pop at Simon Cowell last night  saying he is obsessed with gimmicks.

In the latest salvo aimed at Cowell from the BBC1 show, Scot Barbara told how she was booted off his X Factor show in 2007.

And she reckons it is because he looks for "fake" quirks or unusual angles rather than real talent.

The glam gran  given the elbow at the Boot Camp stage  said: "It was mostly gimmicky singers that got in there. Older singers were never taken seriously. The Voice definitely respects you more."

Club singer Barbara, 47, impressed viewers last night with her performance of Wild Horses.

She said she had been spurred on by finding love again after two failed marriages. She recalled: "I hit rock bottom just before my X Factor appearance and it took a year to get over that, get divorced and really move on with my life.

"After 2008 I was back in a happy place and it was all coming together. I've been very, very blessed. I have a boyfriend of two years and we are very happy."

Barbara  who has performed more than 6,000 gigs in a 24-year career  did not know her idol Tom Jones was to be one of the mentors when she applied for The Voice.

Now she is "overwhelmed" that he has picked her for his group. She said: "I think we are quite similar in some ways. We became parents when we were quite young, we worked hard.

"OK he is a massive, massive superstar. But I think he has applied a lot of the same principles that I have throughout my years  work hard and be professional.

"I've always been a fan of Tom Jones. I'm starstruck. He's absolutely brilliant  what a voice he has. And yes, I do have a crush on him."

Tom, 71, gave Barbara a hug and kiss after her song and told her: "You have a wonderful, wonderful voice and I'm proud to have you on my team. We are going to destroy all these other people!"

Barbara, from Falkirk, said former Britain's Got Talent sensation and fellow Scot Susan Boyle had been a "trailblazer".

She added: "Susan really was an underdog and it goes to prove that there is a market for older artists.

"I want to encourage people who have lost their confidence to just go for it. It doesn't matter what age you are, how you are look, what your size is  if you love something with a passion then just don't give up on your dreams."

pages.headline: BGT George gave me best screen kiss
pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S Got Talent winner helped bring out Roxanne Pallett's sexy side as TV vamp
pages.articlebody:
A STEAMY session with Britain's Got Talent winner George Sampson helped bring out Roxanne Pallett's sexy side as a TV teen vamp.

The actress locks lips with the breakdancer-turned-actor as a troubled pupil in Waterloo Road.

Roxanne said: "I never got the popular guy at my school, but in Waterloo Road I get a very steamy make-out session with George.

"His was the best on-screen kiss I have ever had. It was electric."

The former Emmerdale actress added: "George is going to break some hearts. It was a three-hour scene, which will only be about a minute on screen.

"Suffice to say we know each other really well now.

"He is a little stud muffin and has such a gorgeous heart."

Roxanne, who is 29, also used her single-episode appearance as saucy 17-year-old Shelby Dixon in the BBC1 drama to put some demons to bed from her own schooldays.

She says she used to feel physically sick at the thought of school after being tormented by bullies.

She said: "I hated it and would try to think up whatever excuses I could to get out of it.

"I wasn't popular. I was the ugly, hairy-armed mono-browed Greek girl, so the beautiful girls and gorgeous guys didn't want to sit with me.

"I was such a geek, no wonder people laughed at me. Even my school uniform made me look like a misfit  my trousers were too short and my sleeves were too long.

"But I gave as good as I got because it was sink or swim. I might have been small and not tough physically, but I was quick-witted.

"Apparently this one group of girls, who used to tell me that I was nothing, that I was ugly, are still picking on me in forums and websites.

"It actually felt like a massive relief to go back to 'school' and not have those feelings again. Waterloo Road was amazing, it was like the school years that I always wanted."

Her episode as Shelby is emotionally charged, featuring moving scenes of the teen's pain at the death of her mum. But the demanding storyline posed no problem for the star.

She found fame tackling the issue of domestic violence on Emmerdale as Jo Sugden, who was battered by husband Andy (Kelvin Fletcher).

Roxanne said: "I never play vanilla characters. I am always fighting, screaming, or crying. It is interesting and it keeps it fresh.

"It can be quite exhausting carrying all the emotions. I save everything up that I go through and put it into my character. It is like therapy really."

And she says the emotion used in Shelby's scenes of grief was real.

She explained: "I trembled throughout Shelby's scenes. I felt I was getting the shakes from all the emotion.

"When she is talking about how much she is missing her mum, I applied that to when I lost my grandma at the same age.

"It is more raw if you can actually find a parallel in your own life."

Roxanne's own life has had violent moments, too.

In January thugs on a train threatened to set a vicious bull terrier on her, thrusting the snarling beast into her face. She said: "It takes a lot to scare me  I've been through a lot. I haven't had a sugar-coated life.

"It did affect my confidence and for a few weeks I was constantly looking over my shoulder.

"It's horrible to say, but if anyone walked behind me, I would hesitate and wait for them to overtake as I don't like the feeling of someone close behind.

"I'm not as confident as a lot of people make out and it really affected me because my life is not a Jeremy Kyle culture of arguments and fights.

"You shouldn't ever feel like your heart is racing or that you have a lump in your throat when you are on a train or bus.

"I hope never to be faced with anything like that again."

And Roxanne  who also stars in Casualty this month  is still fuming that the yobs were not prosecuted despite being caught.

She said: "I don't want to read in six months that a woman was mugged or a lad attacked or knifed on that train by the same gang.

"They were caught, put on bail for about a month then the police said that because there were three of them and one of me, my witness statement was too weak against theirs.

"I am disappointed in how lenient the legal system is  it concerns me they are still out there."

But if the law cannot protect her, Roxanne has decided she can protect herself.

The tiny star hired Michael Jackson's British ex bodyguard, Matt Fiddes, to teach her self-defence and how to repel an attacker.

She revealed: "It has really helped me build up my confidence. It was amazing to get a one-off with the man himself. He's about the size of five of me.

"At first he said, 'How small are you?', but then five minutes later he was saying, 'How tough are you?'

"It doesn't matter how big you are, how strong you are  it's that ability to feel that you have strength from somewhere inside.

"It's about channelling your energy and passion into a form that could save you, even if it is just to run away. Hopefully I won't ever have to use it, but if I did, I could."

All of this has left Roxanne without much time for a romantic life.

She admits that she and pal Nikki Sanderson, the former Corrie actress, always joke that they will be spinsters until they are 90.

She laughed: "We will be going on Take Me Out: The Pensioners' Special, because both of us never go clubbing, or have an office job where there is a social circle.

"Obviously I was working on Waterloo Road, but I couldn't really pick up a 15-year-old.

"I've got my eye on the door but I'm not on Match.com just yet.

"A few years ago I had my heart broken and I wasn't up to meeting anyone.

"If I met someone who was a good asset to my life and drama-free, then it would be fantastic, but I haven't. I don't trust many people.

"I'm ridiculously picky but I do quite fancy the comedian John Bishop. He's gorgeous.

"I need to go to Liverpool and find myself a John Bishop."

Roxanne's Waterloo Road episode screens on April 11.

And they also blame Roberto Mancini for letting him get away with it. City's boss thinks Manchester United will reclaim their crown if they win their next two games.

There is now a split in the City camp with a growing number of stars suggesting Balotelli's wayward behaviour is tolerated by Mancini.

A source said: "Mario is starting to get on some of the players' nerves.

"He can be a really great character but he seems to think he can live by a different set of rules.

"It isn't good for team spirit when he gets into that place where it really is all about him."

The last straw for fed-up team-mates came on Saturday against Sunderland when he got into a heated bust-up with Aleksandar Kolarov.

Mancini's believes that 3-3 draw with Sunderland  which ended their 100 per cent record at the Etihad in the league this season  will cost them them the title if United win at Blackburn tonight and against QPR on Sunday.

It would leave City EIGHT points adrift before they play their next match at Arsenal at tea-time on Sunday.

Mancini said: "If we go eight points behind then it is finished."

There is now talk Mancini has had enough of Balotelli and will sell him at the end of the season.

But there is no guarantee Mancini will still be there if he fails to lift the Premier League trophy.

Real Madrid boss Jose Mourinho is being mentioned as his replacement while Anzhi Makhachkala chief Guus Hiddink could also come into the picture.

The source added: "Mancini is ranting and raving in all directions and seems to be losing control."

GARETH BALE helped fire Spurs level on points with Arsenal in the battle for third place.

And he roared: "We're back and ready for the run-in."

Spurs are now behind the third-placed Gunners  who lost 2-1 at QPR  on goal difference, with just ONE goal separating the bitter North London rivals.

Bale, 22, added: "We saw the results on Saturday and we knew what a massive win it was for QPR to beat Arsenal. That gave us the opportunity to get back level and maybe even go above them.

"We've been playing well recently, but we've had a lot of bad luck.

"But we showed what we can do against a great footballing side like Swansea and hopefully that will put pressure on the others."

Bale added: "We had to work so hard. The way Swansea keep the ball is unbelievable.

"They've been fantastic this season, but we showed our true class and what attacking class we have."

But the big Serbian believes his Spanish pal has turned the corner and is starting to justify his £50million price tag.

Torres ended a six-month goal drought in the Premier League by scoring Chelsea's fourth in a 4-2 victory at Aston Villa on Saturday.

The former Liverpool man had been provider up to that point, laying two on a plate for Ivanovic with flicked headers.

Ivanovic knows goals will always be what the striker is judged by, so was happy to see Torres on the scoresheet in injury-time.

He said: "It was an important goal for him. Fernando has been going well and playing well all over the pitch.

"He's been doing everything for the team and I think he deserved that goal. He is a great player. Of course he has felt the pressure and so it was important for us to support him.

"We know how good he is. We've seen that every day in training. But at the same time, for him to score a goal was very important.

"But for us, we know how much he has given us. He doesn't just play for himself but he plays for the team.

pages.subdeck: VICTORIOUS ... The Rock
pages.headline: Rock rules at WrestleMania 28
pages.teaser: THE ROCK emerged victorious against John Cena at WWE showpiece WrestleMania 28
pages.articlebody:
THE Rock emerged victorious over John Cena to conclude a rollercoaster night of entertainment at WrestleMania 28.

In a feud which has its roots in a Wrestlecast interview on SunSport in 2007, The Great One tasted glory in his hometown after a high-quality main event almost impossible to call.

As WrestleMania went on air, Cena and The Rock could hardly be split  and the match itself followed the same pattern as first one man seemed to have an advantage, then the other.

At about the half-hour mark, Rock uncharacteristically leapt from the top rope into Cena's arms, who rolled through into his patented Attitude Adjustment finishing move, not for the first time in the match.

It seemed like the end, but Rock kicked out.

From there, Cena smugly looked for a People's Elbow, but Rock countered into a Rock Bottom for the win, sending the Miami crowd into raptures.

To put a movie star who has not wrestled a singles match in eight years over your No1 star and draw is an interesting call by WWE.

But its credibility will be judged in the future, not now. For the moment all we can do is admire a strong effort from two men who deserve credit for pulling one off here.

Many will argue, though, that it was not the match of the night.

Wrestling purists will point to a smashing WWE title match between CM Punk and Chris Jericho, which ended with Jericho tapping out to Punk's Anaconda Vice submission hold.

The two men complimented each other beautifully in the ring and told a great story of Punk getting revenge on Jericho's heel character.

Most, though, I believe, would have given the match-of-the-night night honours to three men who are certified legends of their craft  and who redefined the nature of storytelling in a wrestling context.

Triple H and Undertaker, with Shawn Michaels as a guest referee, pulled every trick in the book and every string of the heart to weave a tale worthy of the bard and leave every fan in Florida and those tuning in at home feeling as exhausted as each man looked.

Triple H's vicious assault with a chair caused sympathetic ref Michaels to nearly stop the match.

To prevent this, Taker put HBK in the dreaded Hell's Gate before Hunter broke the move with a gimmicked sledgehammer to his opponent's head.

Later, Michaels would hit Sweet Chin Music, sending the Deadman into HHH's clutches for a Pedigree  only for Taker to kick out.

The tables were turned, with Undertaker using the move to punish HHH, and eventually a conflicted Michaels would count three after a tombstone.

It was an epic and the three men left arm in arm, completing their journey to the back with a three-way hug.

It was not seen on TV, but there is no doubt their biggest reception of all would have been behind the curtain.

The thing is, these three matches had to come through for WWE, because the first 60 minutes of this four-hour show were a disaster.

In their wisdom, WWE gave Sheamus and Daniel Bryan, two excellent workers who fans genuinely care about, just 18 seconds for a match which consisted of Bryan getting a kiss from his girlfriend and then a kick from his opponent.

It was an astonishing decision and a transparent virtual slap in the face to those who admire the talents of the Irishman and the American Dragon.

Kane pulled a shock win over Randy Orton and Big Show relieved Cody Rhodes of the intercontinental title in two mediocre, unmemorable matches before WWE allowed celebrity Maria Menounos to score a pin over women's champion Beth Phoenix in a tag match.

Menounos, we should point out, had been billed as having broken ribs and a fractured foot. This is hardly putting the shine on your division's mainstay, is it?

Fortunately, the big guns powered through.

In between, John Laurinaitis seized control of both Raw and Smackdown as his team downed Teddy Long's unit, largely thanks to Eve distracting Zack Ryder.

Depending on your allegiance or preference, the night belonged to two legends defining an era, two workhorses putting on a clinic, or two charismatic stars ending a year-long feud in the middle of the ring.

Thanks to their efforts, we have this Mania down as the best in several years.

We award WrestleMania 28 a score of 8.5 out of 10.

pages.subdeck: SPAT ... Balotelli rows with his own team-mates
pages.headline: Mario acted like a selfish spoiled brat... Fergie's loving it
pages.teaser: ALAN SHEARER says Man United boss must be laughing his head off at Balo & Co
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON must have been laughing his head off watching the highlights of Manchester City's game on Saturday.

It was not so much the fact they dropped another two points in the race for the title.

It was the on-pitch implosion lead by Mario Balotelli which will have told him what he wanted to know.

Manchester City are starting to crack.

Balotelli's behaviour on Saturday was a disgrace.

He had spent the whole afternoon wrapped up in his own personal soap opera.

'Why always me' he asked on that infamous T-shirt. 'Why does it always have to be about you?', I would ask.

At a time when City need everyone pulling in the same direction, he acted like a selfish spoilt brat.

For most of the game he was ambling about the pitch looking like a man whose dog had just been run over.

Then when it came to that second-half free-kick moment he turned even his own fans against him.

City were struggling and running out of time when he chose to have a stand-up row with full-back Aleksandar Kolarov over who should take a free-kick.

Whatever the case, it was a moment that smacked of division in the camp.

I have been on the pitch when similar things have happened.

With Blackburn, David Batty and Graeme Le Saux went at it during a Champions League game at Spartak Moscow in 1995.

Then at Newcastle when Kieron Dyer and Lee Bowyer went for each other in 2005  and they were big mates by the way.

It sends out all the wrong messages.

For City it was the low point of the season.

Forget Balotelli's two goals. They needed a big strong performance from him on Saturday.

They needed him to step up to the plate in the absence of Sergio Aguero and he didn't.

To be fair, he was not alone. City were outfought and outplayed by Sunderland in every single department.

Sunderland's Lee Cattermole bossed the midfield, while up front Nicklas Bendtner and Stephane Sessegnon had the beating of Vincent Kompany and Kolo Toure.

And at the back, Matthew Kilgallon and Michael Turner had David Silva and Balotelli in their pockets for most of the game.

Silva looks tired and shot. The rigours of a full Premier Leagues season have clearly taken their toll.

The player who lit up this league in the first six months of the season is now a shadow of his former self. And so are City as a team.

It seems the relentless pursuit of them by Manchester United has worn them down.

I know what that's like as we had it at Blackburn in 1995  and just hung on to get home from United by a point.

The pressure they applied was relentless but what you have to do in those situations is all stick together.

You need to be a collective, determined force, ensuring that you will not crack.

Despite City's late fightback, I saw none of those traits.

It's all slipped through their fingers and, in Balotelli, you saw a man who simply did not want to grab it back.

WOLVERHAMPTON WANDERERS are a fantastic club.

They have a great ground with a great atmosphere and to me they are a proper community football club.

Yet I find myself with little sympathy for their plight right now as they fall headlong towards relegation.

Their bungling in sacking Mick McCarthy and then scrabbling round for a replacement has undermined any chance they had of staying up.

McCarthy got them up, kept them up and was their best chance of staying up.

Terry Connor was on a hiding to nothing when they finally turned to him after failing to get their first, second and third targets.

Despite their perilous position when he went, I still saw enough in the Wolves side under Mick to suggest they could get out of it.

Not any more and those in the boardroom have only themselves to blame.

My best wishes must go out to STILIYAN PETROV as he begins the biggest fight of his life after being diagnosed with acute leukaemia.

In these past few weeks we have really seen how fragile life can be.

A fit and happy footballer one minute and facing an awful scenario the next.

We have also seen how football can rally round at times of trouble.

The reception he received at Aston Villa on Saturday clearly made it a very emotional occasion for him and his family.

It told him, yes, he's in a fight but also that he is not on his own.

Pardew arrived on Tyneside with the club split following former boss Chris Hughton's sacking.

And Gutierrez added: "When he came to the club and after what happened with Chris, it is amazing.

pages.headline: Official: This is the worst Liverpool run for 58 years
pages.teaser: KENNY DALGLISH looked lost and alone as Liverpool's league slump continued
pages.articlebody:
KENNY DALGLISH looked lost and alone as Liverpool slumped to their worst run in 58 years.

Not since 1954 when the charts were dominated by Vera Lynn and Doris Day have Liverpool fans been forced to suffer such a shocking sequence  eight points from 12 games.

Only Wolves have fared worse in the Premier League since the turn of the year.

No wonder Toon fans took delight after their side's 2-0 victory by taunting Dalglish with chants of 'You're getting sacked in the morning.'

With Liverpool's American owners turning the screw on the Kop icon, the one-time untouchable Anfield legend needed all the support he could get from his own team on Tyneside yesterday.

Instead, he suffered F-word abuse from Andy Carroll  the £35million misfit striker he has backed publicly for 15 months.

And was also let down by keeper Pepe Reina, who decided it was a good idea to try to nut Newcastle's James Perch.

Add to that Carroll also being booked for attempting to con the referee into a penalty, and it amounted to one of the worst days in King Kenny's career.

Dalglish even sounded like a beaten politician as he appealed for unity.

He said: "We have got to believe in ourselves and in what we are doing.

"If we do that then we will have a better opportunity.

"We have to learn we are a stronger force if we stick together  and we will stick together.

"It's a disappointment that Pepe is suspended, but that is what squads are for, to handle people's injuries and suspensions."

He added: "We started well enough and looked threatening, but it obviously ended up with a lot of frustration and disappointment.

"We could have had a penalty in the first half and that would have been them down to 10 men but we never got it."

That was in reference to a Danny Simpson handball on the line which ref Martin Atkinson missed.

But Atkinson did not miss Carroll's outrageous dive to win a spot-kick when TV replays showed keeper Tim Krul had not touched him.

If all that and Reina's red card was not not enough, the Kop chief got a lecture in how to play Carroll.

Toon boss Alan Pardew said: "I think Andy is a player who needs to have a game plan that is going to work for him.

"I think Liverpool struggle to find that game plan with him. When we had him here we were probably a little bit more direct than we are now and he was magnificent.

"I felt for Andy. I think he is a terrific lad. He's had a tough year but he will come back."

Pardew also revealed the secret behind Papiss Cisse's double haul. He added: "His English isn't great  I think he's only had one lesson since he's been here.

"We had Africa Day at the training ground on Friday with the food, that probably helped him.

"He had some curried goat and maybe that was why he was fuelled up out there."

Dalglish's men are now an incredible 11 points behind the sixth-placed Magpies  and a humiliating 16 off Tottenham, who are in the final qualifying slot.

And the latest defeat comes just days after director of football Damien Comolli was grilled by owner John W Henry.

Comolli was asked on his trip to Boston to explain why the £100m investment in players had not brought Champions League football back to Anfield.

Carroll's lack of goals  just six in 48 games  was highlighted as his £10m successor Cisse struck twice to take his tally to seven in just seven games.

And fellow big-money buys Jordan Henderson and Stewart Downing started on the bench.

Dalglish was hailed as the returning hero by the Kop faithful last year when he took over following the dismissal of Roy Hodgson.

And although he has won the Carling Cup this season  albeit after they saw off Championship side Cardiff in a penalty shootout  the failure to break back into the top four will not go down well.

Now the FA Cup semi-final against Mersey rivals Everton, with David Moyes' men on a roll, takes on even greater significance.

SWANSEA have vowed to keep Brendan Rogers out of Tottenham's grasp.

Spurs are thought to be keen on the young boss if Harry Redknapp quits to take the England job.

Rodgers has virtually guaranteed safety for his Premier League rookies, who have dazzled with their swashbuckling football.

He has a £5million release clause but Liberty Stadium chairman Huw Jenkins insists the Swans can hold on to their manager.

Jenkins said: "Brendan's done really well coming into the Premier League and the way football is there could be three, four, five jobs coming up in the summer and you never know.

"Obviously things like that are going to be touted about, but we'll do all we can to make sure Brendan stays with us."

Rodgers was in charge at White Hart Lane yesterday  as Swansea lost 3-1 to Redknapp's Tottenham.

And Jenkins added: "We fully also appreciate some of these clubs are going to be looking for managers and perhaps  hopefully not now, but in the future  Brendan may think the time will be right to move to a club in the Champions League.

"But I think that's a while off yet  let's concentrate on what he does for us over the next few years."

pages.headline: High five
pages.teaser: TOTTENHAM boss watched his stars sink Swansea and then told them: Gimme five
pages.articlebody:
HARRY REDKNAPP watched his Spurs stars sink Swansea and then told them: Gimme five.

Yesterday's win over the Welshmen took fourth-placed Tottenham level on points with Arsenal in the North London duel for third spot with just seven games left.

And Spurs boss 'Arry said: "I'd take five more wins because if we get them, we'll have Champions League football next year.

"I'd love to finish above Arsenal if I can but it's more important we get Champions League football next year, that's the key.

"But it's going to be tight, even to finish fourth.

"Newcastle have performed a miracle, they've kept going and you can't write Chelsea off.

"So it was important to get the win here as it's tight everywhere at the top.

"City need to beat Arsenal at the Emirates or it's all over for them.

"Chelsea are still in there. It's going to be so close."

Rafael van der Vaart's first-half opener and two second-half headers from Emmanuel Adebayor gave stuttering Spurs their first win in SIX top-flight matches and cranked up the pressure on the Gunners.

But Redknapp insisted: "I didn't even know that was our first league win in six games. If you'd said to me it was the first in three, I wouldn't have known.

"I don't go home at night worrying that we've not won in three, four or five. I just know we've been playing fantastically well so it wasn't a problem."

Redknapp denied his team had struggled with confidence during their poor run.

He said: "There's never been a problem with belief.

"I've been at clubs over the years where players, when you walk in, look as if their confidence has gone. This lot have been fantastic.

"I've never felt there's been a problem. We just needed a bit of luck, if you like, and it would turn. We were fine."

Van der Vaart fired Spurs ahead in the 19th minute before Gylfi Sigurdsson smashed the Swans level on 59 minutes.

But Adebayor sealed the points for Spurs with towering headers in the 73rd and 86th minutes. Redknapp, of course, is the odds-on favourite to become the next England manager, while Swansea boss Brendan Rodgers has emerged as one of candidates to succeed him at White Hart Lane.

Redknapp said: "What their manager has done for them is fantastic, I can't speak highly enough of them. If everybody looked at how they play, in youth teams, that's how you should play.

"He's got players from Torquay, Stockport, everywhere, and they play, pass the ball and take risks on the ball. They've come up against a better team here. But if you get kids and youth teams playing that way in this country, you'd have better technical players.

"Brendan is fantastic. Not just now, but when he was running the reserves at Chelsea. Frank Lampard snr and young Frank spoke highly of him.

"Look at the way he's got Swansea playing. He will manage a big club one day for sure.

"And look what he's done with little Leon Britton. I had him at West Ham as a kid. He couldn't get a game at Sheffield United and was at Swansea when they almost went out the league.

"When they came back to 1-1 it was game on. They were having a good spell and I wondered if we'd run out of steam, that we couldn't keep it up. But we came good."

Swansea boss Rodgers has now seen his side lose two on the spin.

But he said: "Some of our football against a top side was outstanding. We dominated for large parts of the game.

"The scoreline was harsh on us. But for a team that's been promoted, to come here and play like that was fantastic."

pages.headline: Tottenham 3 Swansea 1
pages.teaser: EMMANUEL ADEBAYOR scored twice as Tottenham went level on points with Arsenal in the race for third
pages.articlebody:
SO the Great North London run seems to have swung back Tottenham's way  just when it seemed all was lost.

Harry Redknapp was at his April Fool's best when he said fourth place is all he wants for Tottenham after they caught up with Arsenal.

Yeah, right.

Minutes earlier, Swans chief Brendan Rodgers admitted 'Arry will "fight Arsenal like mad for third spot".

Ironic, then, that a former Gunner's double lifted the gloom at White Hart Lane and eased the pressure on Redknapp, while at the same time turning up the heat on their local rivals.

Emmanuel Adebayor headed off yet another post-match inquest and his two strikes ended a nightmare league run that stretched back almost two months.

After a blistering start to the season, Tottenham had failed to win since the week Fabio Capello quit as England boss at the start of February.

Five winless matches since thrashing Newcastle 5-0 on February 10 had seen Arsenal achieve a 13-point swing on Spurs and threaten to win third spot by a landslide.

Momentum seems to have swung towards Bill Nicholson Way just at the right time.

Tottenham are only two goals behind Arsenal now  not points, mind, just goals. Crucially the Gunners have to face Manchester City AND Chelsea.

Spurs' run-in is a doddle by comparison, so there was a lot riding on this one.

Rafael van der Vaart's Dutch of class had put Spurs ahead at the interval but Swansea levelled on 59 minutes through Gylfi Sigurdsson.

But just as the gloom appeared to be descending on a sunny afternoon for Spurs, Van der Vaart swung in a wonderful corner and Adebayor rose to head the hosts in front on 73 minutes.

Then, four minutes from time, sub Aaron Lennon  whose every touch was cheered to the rafters  skinned Leon Britton, arrowed in a measured ball and Adebayor's head did the rest.

Until then, this was a battle between a club whose season promised so much and threatened to deliver so little and one whose season promised so little and has already delivered so much.

Only a few weeks ago, Spurs harboured realistic title aspirations although they are far from finished in terms of securing Champions League football.

Newly-promoted Swansea have won the nation's hearts and already secured survival in their debut Premier League campaign.

Before kick-off, these two sets of players had provided more entertainment this season than all the other top-flight teams put together.

It was a platform for high drama and while they did not deliver a classic, it was still enthralling.

Spurs should have been ahead after seven minutes, when Adebayor set up Van der Vaart.

His shot was destined for the bottom corner but came off Neil Taylor for a corner which, amazingly, referee Andre Marriner failed to spot.

Seconds later, Wayne Routledge's 25-yard effort was just wide.

Spurs No 2 Joe Jordan kept barking at Tottenham's frontline to keep pressing Swansea three- quarters up the pitch  and Redknapp admitted afterwards that was the gameplan.

And it worked wonders for the hosts on 19 minutes when Luka Modric spotted Bale's run behind Angel Rangel, the Welshman squared it and Van Der Vaart beat Michel Vorm in style.

Moments later, Bale was in again on the left but Ashley Williams did well to clear ahead of Adebayor.

Vorm then saved Younes Kaboul's header off Van der Vaart's corner to keep Swansea in the game.

Swans' best chance of the half came on 31 minutes when Sigurdsson crossed and Williams beat Kaboul but his header bounced over. Parker then blocked Sigurdsson's blast.

After the restart, Swansea showed for 15 minutes that they pass the ball as well as anyone in the land.

Brad Friedel produced the save of the match to push Sigurdsson's left-foot missile out for a corner.

William Gallas then ran across to thwart Swans' Danny Graham, who was bearing down on goal.

So it was no surprise when the visitors equalised after Routledge set up Sigurdsson to slam his volley in off the ground.

Vorm then produced a string of saves before Adebayor restored Spurs' lead and killed Swansea off.

Kaboul still found time to produce two wonderful blocks to deny Sigurdsson and then Sinclair late on as Rodgers' men showed dogged determination.

Redknapp heaped praise on Rodgers for his work at Swansea afterwards, insisting the Northern Irishman's work should be replicated across the land.

The Spurs boss said: "That is the way to play the game if you want to produce technical players.

"They have come up against a better team today but every youth coach in the country should go and watch them train and learn from them."

Something perhaps for the next England manager to look at closely.

pages.subdeck: THEY THINK IT'S ALL ROVER ... De Gea cannot deny Yakubu but the keeper has bounced back
pages.headline: Fergie hails keeper and says Jones will be skip
pages.teaser: ALEX FERGUSON has saluted the strength and bravery of Spanish stopper David de Gea
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON has saluted the strength and bravery of David de Gea for coming through the loss of form that threatened his Manchester United future.

The young Spaniard faces Blackburn tonight and it was against Steve Kean's team on New Year's Eve that his season hit its lowest point.

A poor performance gifted Rovers a 3-2 win at Old Trafford  and £17.8million De Gea was axed in favour of Anders Lindegaard.

But he has bounced back and literally got to grips with the English game to establish himself as the Red Devils No 1.

United boss Ferguson said: "He has stood up as a man.

"He got a grip of it. He didn't let it get to him.

"The boy has improved with every game he has played and now he's got confidence  and confidence is a great factor for footballers.

"He stood up to the situation. He knew it was a challenge. It took him time to adjust to the different ways of the English game as opposed to the Spanish game and he's shown that now."

The 21-year-old's performance in the 1-0 victory over Fulham last Monday was further evidence of his improvement  particularly in the air.

It was from a late corner which he failed to deal with that Rovers grabbed their dramatic winner at Old Trafford.

But Ferguson is not expecting any repeats at Ewood Park tonight as United aim to go five points clear at the top of the table.

Ferguson said: "He has made fantastic improvement, the boy.

"What we expected was his terrific ability to show and that's what we've seen.

"The area in which he has been criticised was really in aerial balls into the box, like the Blackburn game and the last corner kick into the box. He should have dealt with that better.

"He knew that and he has addressed that."

Ferguson has also heaped praise on another of his young summer signings  claiming Phil Jones is his captain of the future.

Jones joined from Blackburn in the summer for £16.5m and he has been a hit not only in defence but also in midfield.

But Fergie believes the 20-year-old is a leader as well as a great player, which is why he will eventually hand him the captain's armband.

The Scot said: "He's definitely a future captain, there's no doubt about that.

"I said that from the minute he came to us that I thought there was something about the boy."

Patrice Evra is currently caretaker captain while Nemanja Vidic battles back from injury.

The Frenchman will be leading the team out tonight against Jones' former club.

Meanwhile, Ferguson says Darren Fletcher will soon start his battle back to fitness.

Fletcher, 27, has been having an enforced break from the game due to ulcerative colitis and has not played since November.

Fergie said: "Darren's coaching with the reserves and is going to start a programme quite soon in terms of getting his fitness up. But he'll have a go at it and do his best.

"I think the big push will be in pre-season to try and get back to the level he was at."

pages.subdeck: HERO ... Papiss Cisse is mobbed by team-mates after his second goal
pages.headline: Newcastle 2 Liverpool 0
pages.teaser: PAPISS CISSE made it seven goals in seven games for the Toon to heap more misery on 10-man Liverpool
pages.articlebody:
THIS was a rollercoaster tale of two No9s.

One simply cannot stop scoring and is always a threat.

The other is enduring a constant nightmare which looks like never ending.

It does not take a genius to work out who is who. While Andy Carroll was booed and abused for 78 minutes before storming down the tunnel after being subbed, Papiss Cisse's dream Toon start continues.

What a signing the Senegalese forward has been. The man eventually brought in to replace Carroll just seems to have the Midas touch in front of goal. A typical right place, right time merchant.

His double either side of half-time makes it seven league goals in seven games for the £10million January arrival from Freiburg.

That is two more than Liverpool's £35m man has scored in 36 appearances!

What has happened to the Carroll who was a hero on Tyneside during his time at the club remains a mystery.

He started well but faded badly  just like Liverpool.

A happy homecoming this was not. Newcastle, though, loved every minute.

Level on points with Chelsea with seven games to go, it is a scenario beyond any devout Geordie's wildest dreams.Their third win on the spin not only consolidates their top-six slot, it ensured Pardew remains bang on track for European football next season.

The job he has done at St James' Park continues to defy belief. It is as staggering as the slump Liverpool are in right now.

Pards has expertly moulded a team full of passion, drive, determination and quality.

They defended superbly, the midfield controlled the show and the front three of Cisse, Demba Ba and Hatem Ben Arfa ran the Reds ragged.

Remember, Pardew sent out his team minus inspirational, but crocked, skipper Fabricio Coloccini. The fact he was barely missed shows exactly how well Mike Williamson and James Perch performed.

Kenny Dalglish's Reds, now boasting six defeats from the last seven games, are in a slump which could have huge ramifications when owner John W Henry assesses the whole sorry mess.

It was not as if Liverpool started badly. They had all the early chances and Carroll was putting himself about.

Jonjo Shelvey saw a shot deflected wide on three minutes before Martin Skrtel really should have headed home from a corner instead of heading over.

Then came Carroll's moment to ensure he became a true April fool.

The big hitman had done all the hard work on nine minutes. He powerfully, and typically of his time in a black and white shirt, won the ball off Williamson before nipping it past Perch. All he had to do was stay on his feet as he rounded Tim Krul. The goal was gaping.

But instead he fell to the floor in what looked a ludicrous attempt to win a penalty and was booked for his efforts.

Krul, who came through the ranks with Carroll, was furious and angrily confronted his old 'pal'.

Pardew also gave him what for on the touchline soon after. And boos cascaded down from the stands. Welcome home, bonny lad.

Dalglish, never one to raise a massive smile, cut a frustrated figure. But you will not find much sympathy for him in Geordie land.

Even so, on 14 minutes his strugglers should have been given a penalty.

Just moments after Krul had tipped a deflected Craig Bellamy cross on to the bar, the big Dutchman totally missed the ball from the resulting corner.

It hit Williamson and flicked off Carroll, only for Danny Simpson to arm it away from danger.

It was a penalty but not given by ref Martin Atkinson.

Five minutes later, the pain was increased as Cisse tucked in the opener. Ben Arfa, outstanding once again, whipped in a lovely cross and Cisse slipped in behind Skrtel to head home via a post.

The goal spurred on Newcastle and, once Carroll had headed over on 27 minutes, the Kop were always second-best.

Cisse should have doubled the lead five minutes before the break when he headed wide. Yet his deserved double came just before the hour mark.

Danny Guthrie and Ben Arfa combined for a suspiciously offside- looking Cisse to round Pepe Reina before firing the ball home.

The game was up for the Kop  and on 83 minutes came the crowning glory.

Reina tangled with Perch before stupidly pushing his head into the defender's face.

Contact was minimal but Perch collapsed to the ground and, despite Reina's protests, the outcome was always going to be red.

Jose Enrique went in goal, much to the amusement of a packed St James' Park. Not that they needed anything else to laugh about.

Liverpool and Carroll's sorry state, plus their own sustained Euro charge, has already provided enough smiles to last a lifetime.

pages.subdeck: HEAVENS ABOVE ... Kenny's crown is slipping
pages.headline: Why has it all gone wrong?
pages.teaser: SUNSPORT puts Liverpool under the microscope as their year goes from bad to worse
pages.articlebody:
SUAREZ RACISM ROW

LIVERPOOL and Kenny Dalglish handled it all in completely the WRONG way.

Despite his eight-match ban for abusing Patrice Evra the club insisted Luis Suarez was innocent  and its image was tarnished.

DISTRACTION OF CUPS

DALGLISH insisted he would not swap Carling Cup glory for a top-four finish  but the owners may disagree.

They enjoyed a memorable day at Wembley but it has certainly hit their Premier League form.

ANDY CARROLL

THEY bought him for £35million but do not play a system that gets the best out of him.

He is starved of the long diagonal balls he thrived on at Newcastle, is low on confidence and out of the England squad.

POOR SIGNINGS

JORDAN HENDERSON and Stewart Downing have been massive disappointments.

Over the last couple of seasons the club have invested heavily and while Suarez has impressed, the rest have been flops.

INJURY PROBLEMS

LUCAS was ridiculed at the start of his Liverpool career  but he has been sorely missed in his role protecting the back four.

Steven Gerrard missed a chunk of the season and he is a massive loss for any team.

NO SETTLED DEFENCE

INJURIES have played their part in the Reds' unsettled back four with Jose Enrique and Martin Skrtel the only regulars.

Dalglish also switched systems and played three centre-backs against Stoke at Anfield.

FAILURES ON RIGHT

DALGLISH has a problem on who to play on the right wing. Henderson flopped and Dirk Kuyt also got a chance.

Maxi Rodriguez has been underplayed so Carroll has had a lack of quality crosses.

UNCERTAIN FUTURE

AS SunSport revealed yesterday, Liverpool's Yank owners want to know why the club's big-money signings are not performing.

John W Henry has ploughed millions into the Reds but has so far only a Carling Cup as reward.

pages.subdeck: NET GAINS ... skipper Andrew Strauss pushes himself to the limit during practice
pages.headline: Only Strauss himself will make the call to quit
pages.teaser: ANDREW STRAUSS will decide when he should finish as England Test captain
pages.articlebody:
THE only person who will dump Andrew Strauss as England Test captain is Strauss himself.

There is no chance the selectors  or coach Andy Flower  will remove Strauss as leader of England's five-day team before the start of the summer.

But the Middlesex star could decide to stand down if England lose the Second Test against Sri Lanka here tomorrow and he fails again with the bat.

Strauss, 35, is not the sort to hang around if he believes he has overstayed his welcome or has become a liability to the team  he quit as one-day skipper last year when those at Lord's wanted him to continue.

Strauss has scored just one century in his last 48 Test innings and England have lost four Tests on the trot.

When they lost five on the spin in Australia in 2006-07, the ECB ordered a detailed review into why England were so bad!

After last week's 75-run defeat in the First Test, Strauss refused to answer questions about whether he thinks he has taken the team as far as he can.

A big innings or an England victory in the Second Test  which starts tomorrow morning  would ease the pressure.

Strauss might not be the best tactician  he sometimes errs on the side of conservatism  but his statesmanlike demeanour and ability to say the right thing show he is a true leader.

Alastair Cook, his heir apparent and already captain of the one-day team, does not possess those qualities. Not yet, anyway.

Strauss is already secure as one of England's most successful captains after Ashes wins at home and away as well as leading his country to the top of the world rankings for the first time.

And he has the complete support of his dressing-room.

Jonathan Trott, the only England batsman to score a Test century this winter, blew the Strauss trumpet yesterday.

Trott said: "I don't think anyone could see Andrew not being England captain.

"Everyone has their ups and downs  you can look at 2010 when Alastair Cook was struggling and then he scored more than 700 runs in the Ashes.

"Cricket can be a cruel game and with Andrew it's probably just a few misjudgements and a bit of bad luck."

Meanwhile, England's plans for their India tour next winter have already been thrown into chaos  because the host Board want two Twenty20 matches squeezed in after the end of the four-Test series in November and December.

It means many unhappy England's stars will not return to the UK until Christmas Eve  a week later than they were originally promised.

pages.subdeck: ANGUISH ... Andy Murray
pages.headline: Bullied
pages.teaser: THE world No 1 jumped on Murray's serve throughout to win 6-1 7-6 in Miami final
pages.articlebody:
ANDY MURRAY was bullied into submission as Novak Djokovic crushed him in the final of the Sony Ericsson Open.

The world No 1 jumped on Murray's serve throughout to win 6-1 7-6 and clinch his first title since his Australian Open triumph in January.

Scot Murray was on the defensive from the start, losing back-to-back service games to concede the first set.

And he admitted he had lost to the better player in stifling hot conditions in Miami.

Murray said: "In the first set Novak served and returned really well.

"They were really tough conditions and long points. It was a pretty long match. Congrats to Novak.

"He played the best tennis all week."

The Scot somehow forced a second-set tie-break, despite being taken to deuce in four of his six service games.

However, Serbian star Djokovic had enough answers to defend his title and reassert his dominance over his long-time rival.

But he admitted Murray's battling qualities had worried him during the second set.

Djokovic said: "Andy was very close to winning the second set.

"The match could have gone either way. I had opportunities to break in the second set and close out the match quicker but then he might have won it later on.

"I thought I played really well from beginning to end. There were a lot of long rallies and they were tough conditions."

Both players will now focus on the clay-court season with Djokovic due to play next in Monte Carlo. He added: "I'm looking forward to a great clay-court season which will hopefully be highlighted by a French Open title."

Murray enjoyed a comfortable week in the Miami sun after he was handed two walkovers en route to the final  most notably when Rafael Nadal pulled out of their semi-final.

However, that may have left Murray slightly rusty in that first set as Djokovic dominated.

While Murray battled back, he managed just one break point in the whole of the match.

And when the second set went to a tie-break, Djokovic surged ahead early on and eventually took it 7-4 with a mis-hit Murray forehand to give the Serb a third Miami title.
